article_title: Audience, Time, and Space of Dance
description: Topics related to dance creation and performance
text:
In the Philippines, dances have been performed in various combinations of time and space and for various audiences and occasions—from the ethnic village to the Hispanic pueblo to the contemporary urban Westernized centers. Philippine geography and climate have allowed rituals and dances to be performed in the open air, on hills or by streams and seashores, as well as in houses. Ceremonies and dances mark social and religious functions, or the occasions for planting, fishing, or hunting. These may be performed for the well-being and strength of the group or community.

Ceremonies and social interaction often specify dance venues suited to the lifestyle of the group and/or the purpose of the ceremonies. The Sama Dilaut (Badjao) and the Sama/Samal dance at sea on outrigger boats for special occasions such as weddings. This practice was probably the origin of the pangalay ha pattong, a dance that requires balancing on bamboo poles. The lunsay of the Jama Mapun is danced on a special floor placed on top of the original house floor. In this truly communal event, dancers in a line coil or circle all day long, stopping only to eat, drink, or rest. The Maranao kalilang feast is launched in the open air with a procession of musicians, dancing women, and men on horseback before the datu and his lady. The kapanirong a ganding presentation follows, including the singkil dance and the playing of thekulintangandkagandang.

 

Time and place are more regulated for ritual dances where the community prays for its own welfare and everyone’s health, especially the children’s. The Subanon build abuklog, a temporary high ceremonial platform, on which the community dances together. In the center of this capacious pliant stage is a pestle that pounds into a mortar that resounds against jars dug into the ground. The communal event is also called buklog. It has sexual suggestions and mythical roots often mentioned in epics and tales. During the full moon, the Mamanwa stage a prayer ceremony with dancing, led by a shaman and his assistants. It is addressed to Magbabaya, the supreme being, and the spirits of the dead. A gong, drum, and guitar accompany the proceedings.

The Mandaya also have the many-phased balilig ritual. For this ritual, the Mandaya usually prepare an outdoor altar calledantallmade of various kinds of wood tied together with rattan and decorated with plants, herbs, and lizard-like carvings calledpalla-os. Its center is painted with charcoal and red juice. To its north is a statue calledinutaw-utawrepresenting the spirits. A ceremonial bamboo pole has an open boiled egg at one end. Juice,siklat(chewing condiments), and boiled rice are offered together with a little symbolic carved boat. In one phase of the ritual, thebasalldrum is beaten inlisagstyle for the women to dance to and inkassalstyle for the men until the dancers are in a trance. In another phase called diwatahan, offerings of clothes, jewelry, lime containers, and a bolo are presented to theabyan(befriendedbusawor spirit) of thebalyan(shaman). In the sayaw part, the balyan, with her assistants, wearinglinagkaw(ceremonial skirt), withsallawtananordagmay(veil),kalasag(shield), andkuyab(fan), dances and goes into a trance under the sun. The beating of drums and the sacrificial pig please the spirits. The balyan and her abyan take up a dialogue called pagpanganito. At the end, the shaman stabs the pig to slow death, sucks its blood, bites into its flesh, and smears the sick with blood to protect them.

Ritual dancing may also happen under or inside the house. The Mandaya anito baylan, a ritual to heal the sick, is done beneath the house. A babaylan brandishes her shield and ax (to which noise-making shells have been attached) to the beating of agimbaldrum. But most ritual dances are done inside the house with the required altar and offerings. The Tagbanwa in Palawan perform the pagdiwata to thank Magindusa, the highest of deities, after a rice harvest and to ensure good fortune. With the ceremonial swing and offerings oftabad(rice wine), rice cakes, jewelry, cloth, and other things, the male or female babaylan officiates during the last three days of the full moon and after three or five preparatory lima ceremonies so that the spirits can see and participate. The percussive music of thegimbal,agong, smaller gongs, andbabandilaccompany the dancing, singing, smoking, chewing of betel nut, drinking, and other ritual acts of the babaylan and his/hertaga-iring(assistants). Dancing includes balancing on the head a bowl filled with rice, betel, pepper, and a lighted candle, or a kris or a long-stemmed plant. The family assists as a sodality while the rest of the chosen community attends. The ceremony can last for half a day or more.

The Kalinga gabbok is held in thanksgiving three or four months after a child’s birth. A spirit medium leads the ceremony among relatives and friends with songs and sacrifices of chicken or pig. The say-am of the Isneg marks a headhunt, building a house, a harvest, or the end of mourning. It starts in the afternoon and may go on for five uninterrupted days. Friends and relatives participate. The house is decorated, food prepared, a shaman engaged. Themanganitoor shaman first communes with the spirits. The shaman beats a drum and gongs and soon enters a trance. A dog is sacrificed. The tungtung is the climax, where a mat is laid with a flat stone, a red rooster tied in a corner of a room, and wall decor hung from the ceiling. The men and women dance around the mat and pound with bamboo poles the boulder on which the shaman dances and chants. Other women shower grain on the dancers, while the rest sit in silence.

Dances imitative of animals, plants, occupations, and courtship mark other aspects of the life cycle. The Agusanon Manobo go to the fields and imitate squirrels in the kinugsik-kugsik on large tree trunks. It is also a courtship dance with two males pursuing a female. The forest clearing is the setting for the planting cycle and courtship dances of the Blaan and the Matigsalug, and the propitiatory dance to thediwatafor a good harvest or fortune in the dugso among the Higaonon. The open field is the original locale for all dances that pertain to the rice cycle of planting, harvesting, winnowing, pounding, and the associated mimetic dances of the tinikling, itik-itik, and pabo. There are bird dances, such as the Manobo binanog, Mandaya kinabuwa, and Blaan aral kafi —all imitating hawks. Occupational dances of the Aeta, which are performed in the open, depict the gathering of potato and honey, or imitate martial activities such as duel and torture. The occupation dance ontuba(coco wine) gathering, mananguete, and the mock war dance, maglalatik, both associated with the coconut, entertain the folks outdoors. The Aeta talik paro imitates shrimps by the river stones. The Bicol gold-panning dance, pabirik, originated along rivers. The cleansing ritual of the Bagobo, pamalugu, that includes the transformation of young men intobagani(warriors aiming for the strength of eagles), is also done by streams. Related to the ethnic customs, the salibanda of Paete, Laguna, in which the image of the Santo Niño is bathed, is also done along rivers.

The blue crabs imitated in sayaw sa lambay in Leyte, like the imitative fish dance tahing baila of Jolo, could only have originated by the seashore. The same can be said of the oasioas, which imitates fireflies and originally served to signal and guide the fisherfolk to come ashore. The sala ti alat of Camiling, Zambales, has the dancing fisherfolk coming in with baskets after a fishing expedition. The Samar dance an labasero has fisherfolk vending their catch and walking home along the shore. Mudfish is caught with a handheld fish trap and a gas lamp on the fisher’s hat in the dance pandanggo sa bulig, commonly performed in Bulacan in relation to the fluvial festival, Pagoda sa Wawa.

Much of the dancing in the Cordillera is done by inhabitants of communal houses in the open on hills and mountains. The Igorot feast of the cañao has relatives and neighbors dancing around a bonfire to drive away evil spirits that may prey on the sick. Before a headhunt, supposedly propitious when the firetrees are in bloom or when a wrong must be avenged, the Kalinga watch for the ominous bird,idaw. Amandadawak(priestess) invokes ancestral spirits. The successful hunters calledmingerfinally enact the headhunt, the purification after the mortal combat, and the victorious dance,takiling, where they are rewarded with crowns oflawi(a feathered headdress). The tengao in Benguet is a harvest festival with feasting, gong playing, and dancing on hills aflame with bonfires. The Bontok manerwap, which solicits rain, may last for days until the rain comes. The men go to the hills with baskets of chicks whose chirps supposedly address the spirits. The men dance around bonfires at night and in the daytime wash their gongs and sacrifice a pig.

Returning to the house of the master of the feast, the people placed branches on an altar, ate, drank, and danced. The master and his followers asked the spirit, Drago,for a favor. A second “feast of women” gathered the people at the chief or master’s house, where they drank sugarcane wine, made music, and danced until the next morning.

Spanish colonialism and its state religion changed the lives of Filipinos forever. Roman Catholicism became the dominant religion with the church as the center of the people’s social and spiritual life. The town plaza, surrounded by the church and town hall, witnessed the start and end of processions. The old ritual dances were adapted to honor Christian saints, the way the komedya and sarsuwela performances did. During the Spanish colonial period and to the present in rural Christian towns, dances have been performed as part of the celebration of events in the Catholic liturgical calendar or during the feasts of the town’s patron saints.

In contemporary times, the community continues to participate in the processions, holding tapers or bearing theandas(platform) of the images being honored or dancing and singing as a form of prayer or vow. Processions on the feasts of patron saints are held in daytime or at night. The image of Maria Salome is fetched in the patio of Santa Isabel, Malolos, after the Easter Sundaysalubongand carried for a kilometer to hervisitaby dancing devotees. The celebration brought about the sayaw Santa Isabel. This custom of thedapitor fetching religious images from houses and carrying them to church highlights Tagalog religious feasts. In Pakil, Laguna, people honor the Virgin Mary whose image was supposedly found in the lake in 1640. Since then, it has been fetched from the church every year, and brought to the shore and back, while people sang and danced the turumba. In Makati, Rizal, the songs and dances of the panatang sayaw are performed on Jun 28 and 29 by 13 young girls in honor of San Pedro, San Pablo, and the Virgen de la Rosa in front of the church.

The Virgin Mary is as central to the salubong on Easter Sunday as her risen son Jesus whom she meets underneath the four-posted structure calledgalileain or near the churchyard. Young women in pretty dresses and hats wave flags of all sizes and colors while dancing the bati under the galilea or a stage nearby. In the Visayas, the Santo Niño is honored in the street dancing of the ati-atihan in Aklan, the sinulog in Cebu and Bohol, and the more recent dinagyang in Iloilo, all tied to church events. Ati-atihan dancers paint themselves black with soot and sport fantastic costumes. The sinulog, also called sin-ug, is danced in front of the church to assure good weather and ask for personal favors. In May, in Obando, Bulacan, women dance in a street procession that ends in the churchyard to celebrate the feast of San Pascual Baylon, Santa Clara, and the Nuestra Señora de Salambao. The ritual is meant to obtain husbands for single women, offspring for childless couples, as well as a good harvest.

Plays with dances, such as the komedya which features elaborately choreographed skirmishes between Christians and Moors called batalla, and the sarsuwela or musical plays on domestic themes which sometimes showed fashionable dances, were often held on outdoor stages erected at the church patio. At the turn of the century in Manila, both komedya and sarsuwela were also performed inteatrosor indoor theaters for paying audiences.

At Christmas, many towns enact the pastores de belen (shepherds of Bethlehem) in song and dance on the streets and before houses. Carolers are called cumbancheros in Leyte and daigon in Cebuano and Ilonggo-speaking regions. People dance and drink on tall, large water floats calledpagodaduring fluvial processions, as seen in the Peñafrancia in Naga, and that of the Santa Cruz in Wawa, Bocaue, Bulacan.

In urbanized centers during the American colonial period, social dancing was seen primarily in formal balls in Malacañan or in grand hotels, mansions, clubs, and cabarets. Today, most social dancing is done in night clubs scattered all over Metro Manila and provincial cities. In urban centers, much of the dancing is indoors and done at night to the latest pop hits performed by live bands or played by disc jockeys. Dancing is also seen in variety shows on TV and in film musicals.

In major cities, dance theater performances are usually held in formal, closed venues, with proscenium-type stages, and are seen by paying audiences of matinee or evening shows during the regular annual seasons of dance companies. The same closed venues were used for bodabil or stage shows. In less urbanized places, the school gymnasia, the all-purpose halls (usually inhospitable to staged ballets), and recital halls of all shapes and sizes may be the site of dance performances. Dumaguete enjoys the well-appointed Luce Auditorium of Silliman University.

Metro Manila also has had several theaters. Popular venues for performances during the 19th century were the teatros, like the Teatro de Tondo, Teatro de Arroceros, and Teatro Zorrilla, which had proscenium stages with front curtains, a series of backdrops and flats, a paying audience seated on the orchestra, and several balconies. Similar to these teatros were the Manila Grand Opera House and the Manila Metropolitan Theater of the American colonial period. Immediately after World War II, Trudl Dubsky-Zipper’s Manila Ballet Moderne (MBM) performed in the bombed out city of Manila at the surviving Rex Theater. On the other hand, her husband Herbert Zipper conducted the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) in the ruins of Santa Cruz Church. He always conducted the MSO for all the music in MBM’s presentations.

The postwar years saw the rise of venues that showed mixed programs of films and bodabil, like Clover Theater and the new Manila Grand Opera House, as well as venues for academic programs and performances, like Far Eastern University (FEU) Auditorium, St. Paul College Fleur de Lis Auditorium, and University of the East Theater. From the 1960s, various auditoriums and theaters have been established for all kinds of performances or events, among them: the Philamlife Auditorium, Araneta Coliseum, New Frontier Theater, University of the Philippines (UP) Theater, UP Abelardo Hall, Rizal Theater, Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas aka Folk Arts Theater, Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino, and Tanghalang Huseng Batute of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), Meralco Theater, Conching Sunico Hall and Tanghalang Dalubdulaan of the reconstructed Manila Metropolitan Theater, and the Resorts World. In Manila, there have also been a variety of nonproscenium outdoor stages at Rizal Park, Fort Santiago, Puerta Real in Intramuros, and even in cemeteries like Paco Park.

Dancers have used regular proscenium or thrust stages innovatively. Alice Reyes broke the fourth wall by allowing dancers to come from the auditorium to go onstage, as in her modern pieces, Company, 1970, and Tommy, 1972. In 1971, Basilio also broke the barrier by using the rising and descending orchestra pit as the grave in The Resurrection of Lazarus. From 1990, Enrico Labayen enlarged the spatial dimension with the use of ropes for his multigravitational productions like Icarus in the early 1990salthough there were earlier occasions for dancers descending from the flies in El Gabriel’s Olympiad, 1969; in Luminita Durnitrescu’s The Sleeping Beauty, 1980; and Edna Vida’s Peter Pan, 1983.

But dance performances were also staged in unconventional venues in the 1970s and 1980s. Ballet Philippines performed in the CCP’s main gallery, an event directed by Johnny Manahan, while Dance Theatre Philippines (DTP) opened an art exhibition at the former Museum of Philippine Art with a dance presentation. Manila Metropolis Ballet used to take its portable stage to outdoor spaces such as Fort San Antonio Abad and Nayong Pilipino, as well as to the ballroom of Manila Peninsula Hotel. The Glorietta in Makati Commercial Center had an open and in-the-round stage that occasionally hosted dance concerts. Lawn performances at UP Diliman included two productions of Wisnusubroto Sunardi’s Ramayana in the late 1970s and early 1980s. Studio space has often been used by dance majors and the UP Dance Company for the studio-choreo series at the UP College of Music (UPCMu).

Churches offer venues for dance chorography. In 1992, the UP Dance Company performed Basilio’s Misa Filipina (Filipino Mass) at the altar of the Santuario de San Jose. The work was previously seen at the altars of the UP Protestant Chapel and the Manila Cathedral, performed by DTP in 1985. Other church performances include Shona Mactavish’s The Lord’s Prayer and Julie Borromeo’s dances for Benjamin Britten’s Noah’s Flood, both at the Episcopalian Cathedral in Quezon City. Mactavish also staged liturgical dances at the Presbyterian sanctuary in Silliman University. During the inauguration of the artists’ village of the Asian Institute of Liturgy and Music in 1992, the liturgical dance Dugso was staged outdoors. BP also contributed to Basilio’s Doxology duet at the altar of Ellinwood Malate Church in 1970.

Taking off from both traditional and contemporary influences, dancing in the streets has proliferated nationwide from the 1990s to the present. New or old, these street events last the whole day. They coincide with religious or civilian fiestas, either to venerate respective patron saints, or to mark anniversaries and promote local produce. When favorable, they combine these motives as thematic strategies. These themes may also draw on and from folkloric or invented movements with which certain places may be identified.

Naga, Camarines Sur, combined ecclesiastical and municipal aims in the Voyadores (Voyagers), a group street dance that is now a counterpart of the fluvial parade to celebrate the Virgin of Peñafrancia. Tacloban used to highlight their past with street-dancing in Pintados (Painted People). Camiguin Island‘s own festival centers on itslanzonesfruit produce. Contingents in these four events go around dancing on the streets and end in either a municipal plaza or a sports arena. Up north in Santiago, Isabela, the reason for festival dancing is communality in Pattaradday (Social Harmony). Baguio City holds the Panagbenga (Flower Festival) around the theme of flowers for which the city is famous. In Negros Occidental, the MassKara (Mass of Faces)was initiated to lift the people’s spirit after the fall of the sugar industry. Davao’s Kadayawan (Goodness) honors the city’s varied cultural heritage in Mindanao.

Many of these regional festivals now join the street dancing called Aliwan (Fun) in Pasay. Offering bountiful awards for the dancing, the floats, and the beauty queens, it is organized by the Manila Broadcasting Company and packaged as popular entertainment. Commercialism characterizes the event, with big sponsors, popular entertainers on floats, and politicians in the audience. The pompous event brought in the idea of competition. The audience is now divided into spectators and jurors. The former, composed of curious city audiences, may simply enjoy the parades while awaiting the rankings made by the latter.

Independent or nonmainstream dancers hold events in their own dance studios, like the noted ones of Myra Beltran in Quezon City and of Agnes Locsin in Davao City. Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa’s AlunAlun Dance Studio in Antipolo City and Handog Center in Marikina City likewise serve as a spaces for performances. Earlier prototypes were the old studios of Julie Borromeo in Mandaluyong, Sony Lopez Gonzalez and Joji Felix Velarde in Sampaloc, and Leonor Orosa-Goquingco in Quezon City. Those studios opened to lawns and gardens of their residences, as does the quadrangle lawn of the Shirley Halili-Cruz School of Ballet.

Today, members of Contemporary Dance Network (CDN) entice audiences to their small or cramped studios, like those of Airdance and Chameleon Dance Theater in Quezon City, and of Lyceum of the Philippines University Dance Company and St. Benilde College Romancon Dance Company in Manila. CDN also holds site-specific performances in train stations, underpasses, streets, lobbies, facades and lawns. This mode recalls the street theater at the height of political protests in the 1970s and 1980s.Now and then, museums and galleries host dance events with visual artists called performance art. These spaces provide venues for cutting edge and on-the-spot ventures.

The UP Dance Company presents dance productions in the UPCMu dance studio or on its lawn quadrangles. One that moved from spot to spot was Al Bernard Garcia’s full-length production, Sulog sa Kinabuhi (Flow of Life), which was inspired by the Subanon way of life. Also held on the UPCMu open grounds was Nasalapu-an (Birthing), by Angella Betina Carlos and Japhet Mari Cabling, based on the Panay Bukidnon’s binanog (eagle/hawk dance) and rituals during birth. Accompanying the piece was the voice of a chanter from Panay and the original music of Toni Muñoz which combined bamboo flute and djembe drum. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

During the Spanish colonial period and to the present in rural Christian towns, dances have been performed as part of the celebration of events in the Catholic liturgical calendar or during the feasts of the town’s patron saints.

In contemporary times, the community continues to participate in the processions, holding tapers or bearing theandas(platform) of the images being honored or dancing and singing as a form of prayer or vow. Processions on the feasts of patron saints are held in daytime or at night. The image of Maria Salome is fetched in the patio of Santa Isabel, Malolos, after the Easter Sundaysalubongand carried for a kilometer to hervisitaby dancing devotees. The celebration brought about the sayaw Santa Isabel. This custom of thedapitor fetching religious images from houses and carrying them to church highlights Tagalog religious feasts. In Pakil, Laguna, people honor the Virgin Mary whose image was supposedly found in the lake in 1640. Since then, it has been fetched from the church every year, and brought to the shore and back, while people sang and danced the turumba. In Makati, Rizal, the songs and dances of the panatang sayaw are performed on Jun 28 and 29 by 13 young girls in honor of San Pedro, San Pablo, and the Virgen de la Rosa in front of the church.

The Virgin Mary is as central to the salubong on Easter Sunday as her risen son Jesus whom she meets underneath the four-posted structure calledgalileain or near the churchyard. Young women in pretty dresses and hats wave flags of all sizes and colors while dancing the bati under the galilea or a stage nearby. In the Visayas, the Santo Niño is honored in the street dancing of the ati-atihan in Aklan, the sinulog in Cebu and Bohol, and the more recent dinagyang in Iloilo, all tied to church events. Ati-atihan dancers paint themselves black with soot and sport fantastic costumes. The sinulog, also called sin-ug, is danced in front of the church to assure good weather and ask for personal favors. In May, in Obando, Bulacan, women dance in a street procession that ends in the churchyard to celebrate the feast of San Pascual Baylon, Santa Clara, and the Nuestra Señora de Salambao. The ritual is meant to obtain husbands for single women, offspring for childless couples, as well as a good harvest.

Plays with dances, such as the komedya which features elaborately choreographed skirmishes between Christians and Moors called batalla, and the sarsuwela or musical plays on domestic themes which sometimes showed fashionable dances, were often held on outdoor stages erected at the church patio. At the turn of the century in Manila, both komedya and sarsuwela were also performed inteatrosor indoor theaters for paying audiences.

At Christmas, many towns enact the pastores de belen (shepherds of Bethlehem) in song and dance on the streets and before houses. Carolers are called cumbancheros in Leyte and daigon in Cebuano and Ilonggo-speaking regions. People dance and drink on tall, large water floats calledpagodaduring fluvial processions, as seen in the Peñafrancia in Naga, and that of the Santa Cruz in Wawa, Bocaue, Bulacan.

In urbanized centers during the American colonial period, social dancing was seen primarily in formal balls in Malacañan or in grand hotels, mansions, clubs, and cabarets. Today, most social dancing is done in night clubs scattered all over Metro Manila and provincial cities. In urban centers, much of the dancing is indoors and done at night to the latest pop hits performed by live bands or played by disc jockeys. Dancing is also seen in variety shows on TV and in film musicals.

In major cities, dance theater performances are usually held in formal, closed venues, with proscenium-type stages, and are seen by paying audiences of matinee or evening shows during the regular annual seasons of dance companies. The same closed venues were used for bodabil or stage shows. In less urbanized places, the school gymnasia, the all-purpose halls (usually inhospitable to staged ballets), and recital halls of all shapes and sizes may be the site of dance performances. Dumaguete enjoys the well-appointed Luce Auditorium of Silliman University.

Metro Manila also has had several theaters. Popular venues for performances during the 19th century were the teatros, like the Teatro de Tondo, Teatro de Arroceros, and Teatro Zorrilla, which had proscenium stages with front curtains, a series of backdrops and flats, a paying audience seated on the orchestra, and several balconies. Similar to these teatros were the Manila Grand Opera House and the Manila Metropolitan Theater of the American colonial period. Immediately after World War II, Trudl Dubsky-Zipper’s Manila Ballet Moderne (MBM) performed in the bombed out city of Manila at the surviving Rex Theater. On the other hand, her husband Herbert Zipper conducted the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) in the ruins of Santa Cruz Church. He always conducted the MSO for all the music in MBM’s presentations.

The postwar years saw the rise of venues that showed mixed programs of films and bodabil, like Clover Theater and the new Manila Grand Opera House, as well as venues for academic programs and performances, like Far Eastern University (FEU) Auditorium, St. Paul College Fleur de Lis Auditorium, and University of the East Theater. From the 1960s, various auditoriums and theaters have been established for all kinds of performances or events, among them: the Philamlife Auditorium, Araneta Coliseum, New Frontier Theater, University of the Philippines (UP) Theater, UP Abelardo Hall, Rizal Theater, Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas aka Folk Arts Theater, Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino, and Tanghalang Huseng Batute of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), Meralco Theater, Conching Sunico Hall and Tanghalang Dalubdulaan of the reconstructed Manila Metropolitan Theater, and the Resorts World. In Manila, there have also been a variety of nonproscenium outdoor stages at Rizal Park, Fort Santiago, Puerta Real in Intramuros, and even in cemeteries like Paco Park.

Dancers have used regular proscenium or thrust stages innovatively. Alice Reyes broke the fourth wall by allowing dancers to come from the auditorium to go onstage, as in her modern pieces, Company, 1970, and Tommy, 1972. In 1971, Basilio also broke the barrier by using the rising and descending orchestra pit as the grave in The Resurrection of Lazarus. From 1990, Enrico Labayen enlarged the spatial dimension with the use of ropes for his multigravitational productions like Icarus in the early 1990salthough there were earlier occasions for dancers descending from the flies in El Gabriel’s Olympiad, 1969; in Luminita Durnitrescu’s The Sleeping Beauty, 1980; and Edna Vida’s Peter Pan, 1983.

But dance performances were also staged in unconventional venues in the 1970s and 1980s. Ballet Philippines performed in the CCP’s main gallery, an event directed by Johnny Manahan, while Dance Theatre Philippines (DTP) opened an art exhibition at the former Museum of Philippine Art with a dance presentation. Manila Metropolis Ballet used to take its portable stage to outdoor spaces such as Fort San Antonio Abad and Nayong Pilipino, as well as to the ballroom of Manila Peninsula Hotel. The Glorietta in Makati Commercial Center had an open and in-the-round stage that occasionally hosted dance concerts. Lawn performances at UP Diliman included two productions of Wisnusubroto Sunardi’s Ramayana in the late 1970s and early 1980s. Studio space has often been used by dance majors and the UP Dance Company for the studio-choreo series at the UP College of Music (UPCMu).

Churches offer venues for dance chorography. In 1992, the UP Dance Company performed Basilio’s Misa Filipina (Filipino Mass) at the altar of the Santuario de San Jose. The work was previously seen at the altars of the UP Protestant Chapel and the Manila Cathedral, performed by DTP in 1985. Other church performances include Shona Mactavish’s The Lord’s Prayer and Julie Borromeo’s dances for Benjamin Britten’s Noah’s Flood, both at the Episcopalian Cathedral in Quezon City. Mactavish also staged liturgical dances at the Presbyterian sanctuary in Silliman University. During the inauguration of the artists’ village of the Asian Institute of Liturgy and Music in 1992, the liturgical dance Dugso was staged outdoors. BP also contributed to Basilio’s Doxology duet at the altar of Ellinwood Malate Church in 1970.

Taking off from both traditional and contemporary influences, dancing in the streets has proliferated nationwide from the 1990s to the present. New or old, these street events last the whole day. They coincide with religious or civilian fiestas, either to venerate respective patron saints, or to mark anniversaries and promote local produce. When favorable, they combine these motives as thematic strategies. These themes may also draw on and from folkloric or invented movements with which certain places may be identified.

Naga, Camarines Sur, combined ecclesiastical and municipal aims in the Voyadores (Voyagers), a group street dance that is now a counterpart of the fluvial parade to celebrate the Virgin of Peñafrancia. Tacloban used to highlight their past with street-dancing in Pintados (Painted People). Camiguin Island‘s own festival centers on itslanzonesfruit produce. Contingents in these four events go around dancing on the streets and end in either a municipal plaza or a sports arena. Up north in Santiago, Isabela, the reason for festival dancing is communality in Pattaradday (Social Harmony). Baguio City holds the Panagbenga (Flower Festival) around the theme of flowers for which the city is famous. In Negros Occidental, the MassKara (Mass of Faces)was initiated to lift the people’s spirit after the fall of the sugar industry. Davao’s Kadayawan (Goodness) honors the city’s varied cultural heritage in Mindanao.

Many of these regional festivals now join the street dancing called Aliwan (Fun) in Pasay. Offering bountiful awards for the dancing, the floats, and the beauty queens, it is organized by the Manila Broadcasting Company and packaged as popular entertainment. Commercialism characterizes the event, with big sponsors, popular entertainers on floats, and politicians in the audience. The pompous event brought in the idea of competition. The audience is now divided into spectators and jurors. The former, composed of curious city audiences, may simply enjoy the parades while awaiting the rankings made by the latter.

Independent or nonmainstream dancers hold events in their own dance studios, like the noted ones of Myra Beltran in Quezon City and of Agnes Locsin in Davao City. Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa’s AlunAlun Dance Studio in Antipolo City and Handog Center in Marikina City likewise serve as a spaces for performances. Earlier prototypes were the old studios of Julie Borromeo in Mandaluyong, Sony Lopez Gonzalez and Joji Felix Velarde in Sampaloc, and Leonor Orosa-Goquingco in Quezon City. Those studios opened to lawns and gardens of their residences, as does the quadrangle lawn of the Shirley Halili-Cruz School of Ballet.

Today, members of Contemporary Dance Network (CDN) entice audiences to their small or cramped studios, like those of Airdance and Chameleon Dance Theater in Quezon City, and of Lyceum of the Philippines University Dance Company and St. Benilde College Romancon Dance Company in Manila. CDN also holds site-specific performances in train stations, underpasses, streets, lobbies, facades and lawns. This mode recalls the street theater at the height of political protests in the 1970s and 1980s.Now and then, museums and galleries host dance events with visual artists called performance art. These spaces provide venues for cutting edge and on-the-spot ventures.

The UP Dance Company presents dance productions in the UPCMu dance studio or on its lawn quadrangles. One that moved from spot to spot was Al Bernard Garcia’s full-length production, Sulog sa Kinabuhi (Flow of Life), which was inspired by the Subanon way of life. Also held on the UPCMu open grounds was Nasalapu-an (Birthing), by Angella Betina Carlos and Japhet Mari Cabling, based on the Panay Bukidnon’s binanog (eagle/hawk dance) and rituals during birth. Accompanying the piece was the voice of a chanter from Panay and the original music of Toni Muñoz which combined bamboo flute and djembe drum.
Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
Dance awards are honorific or financial forms of recognition in dance excellence and may be given for lifetime achievement or for annual or occasional competitions. Dance grants may be venue or financial help given to dance artists by an institution or individual to encourage excellence in dance.

Before the 1960s, the education authorities hesitated to acknowledge the nonliterary, unrecorded, and ephemeral art of dance. Then, there were only school field demonstrations, amateur singing and dancing contests during town fiestas, and dance competitions in schools, villages, carnivals, and on television. In 1949, the Boston University honored Francisca Reyes-Aquino with a doctorate degree (honoris causa), 10 years before a Philippine institution, the Far Eastern University (FEU), gave her the distinction. Reyes-Aquino also received the Ramon Magsaysay Award in 1962 for researching and promoting Philippine folk dances, as did Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa in 2015, for recording and performing the dances of the Sulu Archipelago.

The Patnubay ng Sining at Kalinangan was established by Mayor Antonio J. Villegas in 1963. Given by the city of Manila, this award “recognizes and appreciates individuals/groups who have given their time, effort, and talents for the revival, preservation, propagation, and enrichment of Philippine arts and culture.” As highlight of the annual Araw ng Maynila commemoration on 24 Jun, 42 individuals and companies have been given the award for dance from 1964 to 2014. They are Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, 1964; Philippine Folk Dance Society, 1966; Francisca Reyes-Aquino, 1969; Alice Reyes, Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte, and Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, 1971; Eddie Elejar and Manolo Rosado, 1972; Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula and Lucrecia Kasilag, 1973; Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, 1975; Isabel A. Santos, 1976; Remedios de Oteyza, 1977; Maniya Barredo and Tina Santos, 1978; Rosalia Merino-Santos, 1979; Ricardo A. Reyes, 1980; Nonoy Froilan, 1983; Antonio Fabella, 1984; Ester Rimpos, 1985; Felicitas Layag-Radaic, 1988; Lisa Macuja, 1989; Anna Villadolid, 1991; Ramon Obusan, 1992; Cecile Sicangco, 1993; Agnes Locsin, 1994; Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, 1995; Denisa Reyes, 1996; Gener Caringal, 1997; Julie Borromeo, 1998; Maria Luisa “Inday” Gaston Mañosa, 1999; Luther Perez, 2000; Vella C. Damian, 2001; Edna Vida, 2002; Ferdinand B. Jose, 2003; Enrico Labayen, 2004; Douglas Nierras, 2005; Osias Barroso, 2006; Augustus “Bam” Damian III, 2007; Jared Jehowil Tan, 2008; Larry Gabao, 2009; and the University of Santo Tomas Salinggawi Dance Troupe, 2014.

Manila also confers the Tanging Parangal at Pagkilala in dance, which has been given to Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, 1994; Chito Grajo, 1998; Toni Lopez Gonzalez, 1999; Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFG), 2001; and Myra Beltran, 2007. Manila’s highest award is Diwa ng Lahi, and in dance it has been conferred on Bayanihan Philippine National Dance Company, 2005; Antonio Limcaoco Fabella, 2007; and Shirley Halili-Cruz, 2010.

The Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) and The Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service (TOWNS) Awards are given to young professionals who have distinguished themselves in their fields. Sponsored by the Jaycees, TOYM has honored two dancers: Reynaldo Alejandro, 1974, and Maniya Barredo, 1990. The TOWNS has honored dancers Alice Reyes, 1981, and Lisa Macuja, 1989.

In 1972, the National Artist Award was instituted with objectives similar to those of the Republic Cultural Heritage Awards. In the second year of the Awards, Francisca Reyes-Aquino was conferred the first award for dance for her pioneering work in the “unexampled revival of the folk dance,” and for devoting four-and-a-half decades in tedious collection and revival of folk songs and dances at a time when native culture was being overwhelmed by Western culture. Three more choreographers/dance educators and researchers were conferred the honor: Leonor Orosa-Goquingco in 1976 for her “brilliant pioneering efforts in the difficult art of choreography” and for “confronting the endless challenge of elevating Philippine dance to high creative art;” Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula of the Bayanihan in 1988 for her 30-year work which has “preserved and added a new dimension to the country’s dance tradition, building for the country a rich reserve of international goodwill,” and for reinterpreting “indigenous choreography of Philippine ethnic communities in the realm of theater;” and Ramon Obusan in 2006 whose research and choreographic works have “broadened and deepened our understanding of our cultural life and expressions.” In 2014, Alice Reyes was named National Artist for her extensive work in choreography and dance leadership, particularly with Ballet Philippines.

Although founded in 1977, the Gawad CCP Para sa Sining conferred honors for dance only in 1989. As the principal arts agency of government, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) gives this award to recognize “Filipino artists who have made contributions to their particular art form or field.” Gawad CCP was given to Alice Reyes, 1989; Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte, 1990; the Manunubli ng Sinala, 1991; Maniya Barredo, 1992; Ramon Obusan, 1993; Rosalia Merino-Santos and Teresita Pil, 1994; Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, 1997; Eddie Elejar, 2004; Felicitas Layag-Radaic and Philippine Folk Dance Society, 2008; and Agnes Locsin, 2012. In celebration of the centennial of Philippine Independence, the CCP conferred Centennial Honors in the Arts in 1999. Those honored in dance were Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte, Libertad Villanueva Fajardo, Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, Carmen Dakudao-Locsin, Felicitas Layag-Radaic, and Alice Reyes.

The National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) lifetime-achievement award Dangal ng Harayafor dance has been given to Basilio Esteban Villaruz, 2001, and Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, 2007. The NCCA also gives the annual Gawad Alab ng Haraya to institutions and individuals. For a time, the NCCA national dance committee awarded Pasasalamat ng Bayan sa Sayawto several dance pioneers nationwide during its national conferences and festivals. Among those honored were Fe Sala Villarica, Libertad Villanueva-Fajardo, Carmen Dakudao-Locsin, Maggie Shea, Remedios Villanueva-Piñon, Arturo V. Cruz, Lydia Madarang-Gaston, Lucio Sandoval, Tony Llacer, Douglas Nierras, Emerita Basilio, Elsie Uytiepo-Torrejon, Pancho Uytiepo, and dance photographer Rudy Vidad. That award was patterned after that of the Ballet Federation of the Philippines in the 1970s, given with the seal of Malacañan. Conferred during BFP’s festivals, the honorees then were Luva Adameit, Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Remedios de Oteyza, Anita Kane, Ricardo Cassell, Trudl Dubsky-Zipper, Manolo Rosado, Ruben Nieto, Paul Szilard, Rosalia Merino-Santos, and Fe Sala Villarica.

Annual awards for national and international achievements have recognized Philippine dance artists. The Bayanihan was the first to gain international recognition when it won the Best Group prize at the Brussels Universal Fair in 1958. It also won a string of awards in the US, France, and Argentina. The Filipinescas, FEU, Filipiniana, and Leyte Kalipayan dance companies have won major prizes in Europe. The Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center, and Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe have also been well received abroad.

Over the years, Filipinos have won top honors in international dance competitions in Asia, United States, and Europe, among them dancers Lisa Macuja, Camille Ordinario Jocson, Georgette Sanchez, Gaye Galiluyo, Christine Rocas, Candice Adea, Marcelino Libao, and Jean Marc Cordero. Several Filipino contingents have also won honors in group competitions. In choreography, Locsin took the Prince Takamado Award in Tokyo in 1993, while Douglas Nierras won the grand prix at the Saitama International Creative Dance Competition in Yono City in 1999. For years, choreographer Hazel Sabas gained recognition at home and abroad with her fellowships, choreographic commissions, and directorial awards.

Videodanse-France conferred awards on two CCP dance documentaries, both with direction by Ramon Obusan and script by Basilio Esteban Villaruz. The International Congress on Research in Dance awarded Villaruz for dance research in 2003; for the same he was honored by the National Research Council of the Philippines in 2005. From 1987 to 2001, Villaruz served on the jury of the Asia Pacific International Ballet Competition in Tokyo. Some Filipino dancers have won places in this competition, starting with Lisa Macuja’s silver prize in 1987.

Along with its music counterpart, the National Music Competition for Young Artists (NAMCYA) started a national ballet competition in 2004. This challenged dancers and choreographers nationwide; some went on to win international prizes. The competition was sponsored by the CCP, the NCCA, and the Department of Education. In 2013 the NCCA withdrew support, but the CCP continued it in 2014. Sometime after NAMCYA’s ballet competition, the NCCA’s national dance committee started its own in folk, ballroom, contemporary dance, and neo-classic ballet. In 2008, the Contemporary Dance Network began the WiFi Body Festival that gives awards to young choreographers. This is worked out with the CCP and Japan Foundation, the latter sending winners to Japan to join competitions or festivals. Events like these discover young dancer artists.

With an independent jury, the Philippine Legitimate Stage Artists Association (Philstage) gives annual awards called Gawad Buhayto professional productions and artists in theater and dance with categories in playwriting, choreography, directing, lighting, and production design. The board of directors of Philstage also gives life-achievement awards called Natatanging Gawad Buhay .

On the popular front, there used to be competitions in break dancing; now the attention has shifted to hip-hopdancing. These are held in local and international sites, in categories like Junior, Varsity, Adult, and Megacrew. Hip Hop International’s World Hip Hop Dance Championship is held in various places abroad. Among the Filipino groups which have won top places are the Philippine All Stars, The Crew, Romancon, UPeepz, and the A-Team.

Awards are not the only honors given to individuals and groups which have excelled in dance. Grants are also given by government and nongovernmental cultural institutions to aid dancers and dance companies in the development and popularization of their craft. These may take the form of study grants, venue grants, and travel grants.

Since the 1950s, outstanding dancers have received scholarships for study abroad. Dance awardees were Felicitas Layag-Radaic, Lulu Puertollano, and Alice Reyes. Among the early scholars are Benjamin Villanueva Reyes, who studied in New York supported by the Manila Music Lovers’ Society and the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas; and Joji Felix-Velarde, who was brought by Ricardo Cassell and Alicia Markova to train in England and New York.

For a time, only the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP) supported musicians and dancers who wished to study abroad. Now, foreign governments and their funding agencies award study and observation grants to many dance artists. Among these agencies are the British Council, Goethe Institute, German International Theater Institute, the United States Information Service, Philippine-Soviet Friendship Society of the former USSR, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the Southeast Asian Ministers of Education Organization’s Regional Center for Archaeology and Fine Arts, and the Asian Cultural Council in New York.

Like the MPFP, the CCP has assisted local groups which will represent the Philippines in foreign festivals through its special grants program. After 1986, the CCP also expanded its seasonal residencies for dance companies, accommodating Philippine Ballet Theatre and the ROFG. To “develop artistic excellence” and “promote democratization,” the CCP sponsored a dance grant program by opening CCP venues to local dance groups. Among the grantees from 1988 to 1991 were the Leyte Kalipayan Dance Company, the Dureza Ballet School, Quezon City Ballet of the Halili-Cruz School of Dance, St. Anne’s Dance and Music Studio, Dance Theatre Philippines, Philippine Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe, Ben-Lor Ballet Academy, La Salle Dance Troupe, Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe, Odon Sabarre and the People’s Center School of Dance, Hwa Yi Ethnic Dance Center, Dance Concert Company, Theatrical Ensemble and Artistic Movement, Chameleon Dance Company, Araullo University Dance Troupe, and Sandiwang Kayumanggi Folk Dance Troupe. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Topics related to dance creation and performance
text:
Choreography is the composition of dance which organizes time and space, words, music, sets, props, lights, and dancers in order to realize a concept or story. It is also sometimes called “movement notation.”

Long before the term “choreography” began to be used in the late 18th century, native Filipinos had composed their dances through the ages. Tribes invented and taught dances communally. Shamans designed and directed rituals where they played special roles. Ritual dances may appear improvised, seemingly without beginning, middle, or end; but they actually require a set of movements and even definite costumes, sets, and props. Spontaneity is ruled by both the purpose and objects of worship. The Philippines has numerous ritual dances, such as the Tinguian gabbok to assure a child’s health, the Tagbanwa pagdiwata to plead for a good harvest, and the Mandaya anito baylan to please environmental gods.

Among the ethnic communities, mimetic and occupational dances tend to be sketches that follow the form and style of the subjects or the chronological order of the imitated tasks. The Tausug langka baluang imitates a monkey, while the Ifugaopaypayto represents birds disturbed from their perch by hunters. The Blaan closely imitate the movements associated with each stage of rice planting, in the choosing and clearing of a field, the digging of the ground with poles, the sowing of the seeds, and finally, the harvesting of the rice to the rhythm of thehaglong(lute) and gongs.

European dances were brought over by soldiers, traders, and priests. Although the pandanggo may still follow the triple time and occasional figures and structure of the Spanish original, it has been adapted to indigenous culture and conditions. Thus, the props used may be lighted lamp or candle as in pandanggo sa ilaw,or a native hat as in the pandanggo sa sambalilo. The street pandanggo of Obando, Bulacan, has been performed for a religious feast that may originally have been animistic. Other Tagalog dances are the caracol of Cavite and the turumba of Laguna. In Cebu, the sinulog is performed as a dance-prayer to the Santo Niño.

European dances remained “purer” or “closer to the European original” among the Hispanized elite. These include the jota, balse, escotis, mazurka, polka, and rigodon, which all follow set patterns and procedures. The accompaniment is also predetermined so that even regional variations, such as the polkabal and mazurkaval, are regulated by their music and accepted figures. There are, however, some textural variations specific to Ilocano, Tagalog, or Visayan steps and hand gestures, such as the hand gestures of the kumintang among the Tagalog.

American social dances changed Philippine fashions. Bodabil adapted them for stage shows, giving them a semblance of choreographic order. From the charleston to the rock and roll to the chacha to the twist and the bossa nova, the dances were first popularized by movies and music records. American ethnic dances, such as the clog, tap, and hula, as well as the aesthetic “Orientalism” of Ruth St. Denis who visited the Philippines in 1926, left their mark on Philippine popular culture. Later, discotheques and contemporary bars encouraged highly improvisational dances.

Ballet, on the other hand, features techniques set over the centuries in Europe and a choreography formulated by Marius Petipa in the 19th century in Russia. Realism, formerly espoused by Jean Georges Noverre in the 18th century, was revived by Michael Fokine at the beginning of the 20th century, especially through the Serge Diaghilev Ballets Russes. In the 20th century, George Balanchine, whose abstract ballets have influenced world dance, personified neoclassicism. In the Philippines, Balanchine’s mark is most clearly seen in Remedios de Oteyza’s works, which are set to European concert and symphonic music.

The abstract form was given Philippine touches by later choreographers. Julie Borromeo’s Zagalas de Manila (Young Maidens of Manila), Felicitas Layag-Radaic and Julie Borromeo’s Mir-i-nisa, Eddie Elejar’s Katakata sin Rajah Indarapatra (The Story of Rajah Indarapatra), Basilio’s Tropical Tapestry, Brando Miranda’s Lawang Paoay (Paoay Lake), and Enrico Labayen’s Songs are prominent examples.

The freer style of modern dance was, at the start, even more form-oriented. Philippine choreographers were influenced by Trudl Dubsky-Zipper from the 1930s to the 1960s: Doris Humphrey, Louis Horst—who worked closely with Martha Graham, and Hanya Holm—who taught Alice Reyes. Philippine modern dance has been closely tied to Western dance forms.

Leonor Orosa-Goquingco stylized folk material in Trend: Return to Native, Noli Dance Suite, and Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend and Lore in Dance. Rosalia Merino-Santos’s lecture-demonstration titled“What is Dance?,” itself a compositional lesson, emphasizes inventiveness. Alice Reyes’s works balance form and invention. Adopting a Philippine story, she invents her movements, as seen in the stark Amada and Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf), the intricate Company, and folkloric At a Maranaw Gathering and Bungkos Suite (Bundle Suite). Others followed suit: Corazon Generoso-lñigo’s Baile deAyer (Dance of Yesteryears) and Lam-ang, Gener Caringal’s Ang Sultan (The Sultan) and Labaw Dunggon, Antonio Fabella’s Filipino Pop Songs, Denisa Reyes’s For the Gods, and Agnes Locsin’s Bagobo. To processes like these, many other examples have come about through the years. Of epic proportions are Denisa Reyes’s Realizing Rama for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, Caringal’s Darangen ni Bantugen (Tales of Bantugen) for Philippine Ballet Theatre,Locsin’s Hinilawod for Dagyaw Theater and Dance Company (DTDC), Sergio Gahol and Elena Laniog’s dance-drama Labaw Donggon: Ang Banog ng Sanlibutan (Labaw Donggon: The Hawk of the Universe) for Ateneo’s ENTABLADO.

Basilio explores Panay ethnic forms in Tinagong Dagat (Hidden Sea) for DTDC and in Ang Babaylan (The Shaman) for Teatro Amakan of the University of the Philippines (UP) Visayas. Rudi Soriano interprets Binanog-Banog (Banog Bird Dance) for the Likha dance group in San Francisco. Japhet Mari Cabling and Angella Betina Carlos create Nasalapu-an (Birthing) for the UP Dance Company. In a similar vein, Al Bernard Garcia’s Sulog sa Kinabuhi (Flow of Life) for the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) dwells on Subanon life.

Drawn from history are Caringal’s Andres on Andres Bonifacio and the Katipunan, Locsin’s La Revolucion Filipina (The Philippine Revolution) on Apolinario Mabini and Emilio Aguinaldo, Basilio’s La Lampara (The Lamp) on the last hours of Jose Rizal, and Generoso-Iñigo’s Sisa ,based on Amelia Lapena-Bonifacio’s Ang Paglalakbay ni Sisa (The Journey of Sisa). Alice Reyes’s one-act Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf) on the assassination of Gov-Gen Bustamante and the revenge of his wife was based on an apocryphal narrative attributed to Fr Jose Burgos. Later, Myra Beltran followed this with the full-evening Itim Asu: 1719-2009 (Onyx Wolf: 1719-2009), based on Virginia Moreno’s play The Onyx Wolf .

Folk dance choreographers, such as Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula and Ramon Obusan, stylized ethnic and folk dances for theatrical purposes. They modified the element of time by speeding up, retarding, or heightening dynamics. They reworked the idea of space by enlarging, elaborating, and using floor and space patterns. They explored new themes so the folk dances became larger than the original yet retained their flavor. However, staged folk dances restrict themselves to conventional program length to suit the demands of a marketed theater attendance, which limit choreographic practice to some extent.

Choreographers violated the conventions of the proscenium stage by bringing the action out of the auditorium, thus changing the nature of movements and use of space. Alice Reyes’s Company and Tommy brought performers into the audience area, and in the case of the first work, stripped the stage of its usual curtains and legs. Basilio’s The Resurrection of Lazarus used the rising and falling orchestra pit for the climax, while his Misa Filipina (Filipino Mass) used the church aisle for the procession. Borromeo’s version of Benjamin Britten’s Noah’s Flood had “animals” parading down a cathedral aisle. For Siklo (Cycle), Fabella, aided by Salvador Bernal, inflated and deflated a symbolic cosmic balloon and drenched the upstage with a waterfall. Labayen stretched the dimensions of performance with his multigravitational presentations. Obusan brought to his folkloric presentations a semblance of ritual time and space.

Contemporary choreography increasingly addresses social issues as it also inquires into creative processes. Among Denisa Reyes’s significant works is Suwana for Ballet Philippines. She unravels the external and internal aspects of society with incisiveness. At the UP Diliman, dance majors take deconstruction strategies on dance traditions and situate these in Filipino lives. They composed adapted versions of ballet classics, like Mariang Sinderela,ang Bagong Bayani (Maria Cinderella, the New Heroine) from Cinderella, Maria Clara’s Colonial Dream from The Nutcracker, Higanti (Vengeance) from Giselle, Sa Pula, Sa Itim (In White, In Black) from Swan Lake, Pedro Kusinero (Peter the Cook) from Petrouchka, Sylvia Ligaya (Sylvia Joy) from La Sylphide, and Alicia sa Bundok Dilim (Alice in the Mountain of Darkness) from Alice in Wonderland .For example, Sinderela and Maria Clara dwell on entertainment exported to Japan, Higanti onhacendero-sacada(sugarcane plantation worker) relations, Pedro Kusinero on the US military base in Subic, and Sylvia Ligaya on virtual Internet sex vis-à-vis reality. All of these deconstructions use the vocabulary of contemporary dance. In 2014, Michael Barry Que and Gebbvelle Ray Selga mounted Pavilion IV, a choreographic work placing the audience in the subject-position of both voyeur and patient as a way of critiquing society. The piece was based on the immersion trip of choreographers at the National Center for Mental Health. For some of these productions, composers created new music and dramaturgs provided new perspectives. These joint strategies sustain tradition and innovation in both music and dance.

Since the 1960s, dance groups have performed in museums and outdoors, even on special stages set up in memorial parks and resorts. Dance Theatre Philippines adapted its performances to Rizal Park, such as Borromeo’s Zagalas de Manila (Young Maidens of Manila), Layag-Radaic’s Tanan (Elopement), Fabella’s Limang Dipa (Five Armstretches), and Basilio’s Mosque Baroque. Wisnusubroto Sunardi’s Ramayana was staged outdoors by the lagoon in UP Diliman.

Choreographers have also adapted works for the restricted space of TV by orienting movements to the camera’s eye, and on how figures disappear as they move toward and away from viewer or from one side of the camera to the other, or how they can form patterns for a camera riding on top of a crane. Among these choreographers are Julie Borromeo, Amelia Apolinario, Lito Calzado, Douglas Nierras, and younger choreographers of popular and commercial dancing. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Topics related to dance creation and performance
text:
A dance company is a body of trained artists who execute and produce dances designed and programmed by directors, choreographers, restagers, choreologists, designers, and other personnel. The dancers may train in a specific technique, school, or style with teachers, and may know more than one kind of dance; or they may continue training as they perform. Dancers rehearse and perform the company repertoire, which may consist of both new and classic dances.

A primary ballet company is directly linked to its director’s school. Examples are Pamana Ballet, the Hariraya Dance Company, Dance Theatre Philippines (DTP), Dance Concert Company, Manila Metropolis Ballet, Julie Borromeo Dance Company, and Quezon City Ballet. Among these, DTP stood out, as its three founders ran separate schools and the dancers received regular allowances. Some companies, including DTP, Pamana, and Hariraya have had boards of trustees which raised funds. Manila Metropolis was supported by its subsidiary, Friends.

In 1987, a number of small companies and schools formed the Philippine Ballet Theatre (PBT), the new resident company of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP), complete with trustees, an artistic council, executive board, and office staff. PBT was formed by the Hariraya Dance Company, Dance Theatre Philippines (DTP), Dance Concert Company, Manila Metropolis Ballet, the Ben Lor Academy, and Academie of the Performing Arts. Up to the 2010s, PBT continues to be a seasonal company of the CCP and rehearses at the Meralco Theater.

There are institution-based companies. DTP, for example, performed regularly for the National Parks Development Committee, which subsidized it for 13 years to appear once or twice a month at the Rizal Park. The company ran subscribed seasons at the Meralco Theater for two years. It was resident company at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music, which supported its dancers and subsidized its university performers for seven years. The Alice Reyes and Modern Dance Company started as a private organization which later became a resident company of the CCP, first named CCP Dance Workshop and Company in 1970, then renamed CCP Dance Company in 1974, and finally Ballet Philippines (BP) in 1980. BP’s repertoire of both classical ballet and modern dance and its annual subscribed seasons make the company unique in Asia. As a resident company, it is similar to European companies under an intendant, although more independent with its own board of trustees and other support arms. It also serves other resident drama and music groups and the outreach programs of the CCP. The old Metropolitan Dance Theater (MDT) was based at the Manila Metropolitan Theater. A jazz and modern dance group, MDT enjoyed relative independence and maintained its own school. Other institution-based groups were the dance companies attached to the Central Post Office, Department of Tourism, and other government offices.

In the 1950s, folk dance companies were usually based in schools. The Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company was and is attached to both the Philippine Women’s University’s Bayanihan Folk Arts Center and the CCP. The Baranggay Philippine Dance Company was formerly based at the Philippine Normal College (PNC). The Darangan Cultural Troupe is based at Mindanao State University (MSU) in Marawi, and the Tambuli Cultural Troupe at the MSU in Tawi-Tawi. description: Topics related to dance creation and performance
text:
Dance criticism is the discussion and evaluation of the making, manifestation, and meaning of dance. The making of a dance includes conceptualization and manipulation of dance elements, including attendant designs. Dance is manifested in its performance, which includes audiences, time, and place. The meaning of a dance is its significance to various levels of perception or kinds of reception, and in the development of dance and culture in society.

In the Spanish period, European travellers or Spanish priests concentrated not on dance criticism, but on dance description. In 1521, Antonio Pigafetta described a dance worship of the sun, which he said was led by old women who chanted, drank, and circled around a sacrificial pig while carrying bamboo trumpets and spears (Blair and Robertson XXXIII 1973,169). In 1663, Fr Francisco Colin described the movements of what seems to be a war dance (Ibid., XL 1973, 37-48). In 1846, Mallat described the courtship dance called kumintang (Ibid., XLV, 276).

Dance description is also seen in the 1930s, this time focusing on the so-called modern dance which burst through the boundaries of accepted dance criteria and aesthetic principles. Philippine critics did not confine themselves to description, but continued on to make judgment. In the years before World War II, A. V. H. Hartendorp wrote about Trudl Dubsky-Zipper’s Manila Ballet Moderne in his Philippine Magazine. His descriptions and evaluations of all three annual seasons, which were cut short by the war, give us a fair idea of Dubsky-Zipper’s art.

In the 1950s and 1960s, more and more dance reviews started to appear in newspapers. The most significant dance critics were Morli Dharam (later Anthony Morli) for the Manila Times and Rosalinda L. Orosa for the Manila Chronicle. Like Hartendorp, they were general practitioners who covered musical, dramatic, and choreographic events. Along with Rodrigo Perez III, Edith Hernandez, Exequiel Molina, and Vilma R. Santiago-Felipe, they monitored the dance in those decades. Their pieces consisted mainly of brief descriptions as most critical writing then was given little space amid news and “high society” reportage. Descriptions were mainly adjectival, not always justifying why a dance was well performed or not.

In the 1960s, dance personalities such as Anita M. Kane and Leonor Orosa-Goquingco started writing regular feature articles. Orosa-Goquingco combined teaching, choreographing, and writing about music, drama, and dance. Both she and Kane evaluated productions in the general style, focusing on performance and personality. Orosa-Goquingco continued to write criticism up to the 1980s. Her critical pieces are published in Curtain Call: Selected Reviews 1957-2000, published in 2001. In the 1970s, other writers emerged, such as Isabel Taylor, Josephine Acosta, and Elizabeth Reyes who provided the readers with more analysis and context.


Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, who, like Orosa-Goquingco, has both a literary and choreographic background, also contributed much to dance criticism. In the 1960s, he wrote regular reviews for the Weekly Nation, covering musical, dramatic, choreographic, visual, and even anthropological events for two years. After a long hiatus, he resumed critical writing in the 1970s for BFB Newsletter, later renamed Sayaw Silangan, which he edited and produced for the Ballet Federation of the Philippines. Villaruz’s writings closely observed both choreography and dancing, influenced by critics John Martin and Edwin Denby who were very insightful as they were themselves dancers. He likewise encouraged other dancers to write, among them Felicitas Layag-Radaic, William Morgan, Edna Vida, Lourdes Dalupan, and Teresa Bautista who followed suit and wrote with critical discernment and perspective. Later Villaruz went on to write for Manila Standard and for a new edition of Manila Times.He sat in a criticism class of Jack Anderson at the New School of Social Research in New York and joined conferences for critics at the American Dance Festival and in Hong Kong for the Goethe Institute. Later, Marcia Siegel, who visited Manila, was a distinct influence on him as writer and teacher. For a broader framework, he also drew from theater and cultural critics Rustom Barucha, Homi Bhabha, and the disciplines of sociology and anthropology. Villaruz published several anthologies of his dance criticism in Treading Through: 45 Years of Philippine Dance, 2006,and the three-volume Walking Through Philippine Theater, 2012, which won the 32nd National Book Award’s Alfonso T. OngpinPrizefor Best Book on Art in 2013.

Few critics dwell on the social implications of a piece, putting it in the context of preceding works, personal influences, and social forces. This limitation is caused by newspapers that do not allow lengthy discussion and critics who are incapable of ethnological and sociological analysis. But Villaruz and Thelma Sioson San Juan were fortunate to have been given much leeway and space by the now defunct Manila Chronicle. In the 1980s, new writers joined established critics like Rosalinda Orosa, Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, and Vilma Santiago Felipe. Among them was Pablo Tariman who edited the CCP’s Arts Monthly and wrote for the Observer and later for the Philippine Daily Inquirer .He was generally supportive if not adulatory. Marge Enriquez, who started in Business World but eventuallytransferred to the Philippine Daily Inquirer, has been meticulous and could sometimes be either generous or dismissive. For a time, Edna Vida wrote for both the Manila Times and Philippine Star. In the 1990s, much dance criticism did not go beyond what it was in the 1960s and 1970s.

In the 2000s, Layag-Radaic only wrote intermittently and selectively. Young writers who write criticism backed by academic studies and dance experience include Rina Angela Corpus, whose essays are compiled in Defiant Daughters Dancing: Three Independent Women Dance, 2007, Ruth Jordana Pison, Elka Requinta, Chantal Primero, and Joelle Jacinto. After writing for Malaya, Jacinto published the quarterly Runthru which became an online magazine, and contributed to the World Dance Alliance’s Asia Pacific Channels. Beyond just seeing performances and conscientious probing, these writers broadly contextualize their respective points of view. Their crop is well-versed in worldwide events and issues, and cover both mainstream and marginal groups. They write from current dance theories that are linked to cultural studies. Beyond just seeing choreography and performance, these writers consider the modes of production of the works, declaring sometimes the subject-position they occupy as critics. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Topics related to dance creation and performance
text:
Designs for dance include the sets, properties, costumes, and lighting that create time and place; give a performance atmosphere; and provide symbols, allusions, and layers of meaning. The sets are painted or constructed. Properties or portable implements and costumes identify a character, occasion or action. Lighting may be natural or controlled with torches, candles, gas or electric lamps, spotlights, projections, and other equipment moved or modulated for effect.

Musical instruments like the Tagakaoloudol(plank drum) and the Kalingagangsalend purpose, properties, and accompaniment to the Tagakaolo and Kalinga dances, respectively. The elaboratekulintangstand withokirdesigns provides the setting for Maranao and Maguindanao dancing. The Bukidnon dance the dugso around an altar for their hinaklaran ritual as do the Manobo for their sangga ritual. Calledangkaw(bamboo platform) orsinengseng(a bamboo pole split at one end to support a plate or candle) by the Manobo, these altars are decorated withmenhaw(coconut fronds) and hold offerings of rice, buyo, betel nut, lime, raw eggs, and glasses of water. During the sangga, which addresses coastal spirits, the dancers also offer cigarettes, wine, cookies, and rice cakes. In the pagdiwata of the Tagbanwa in Palawan, elaborate bamboo altars in and outside the house also bear offerings. Thebaylanor shaman, covered by a mysteriousalindugan(a large black hood), sits on a swing, and offers the spirits, among other things, a votive bird, rice wine, rice cakes, and jewelry laid out on a mat. The Subanon set wine and food on a high, resilient bamboo platform calledbuklog, constructed in the open field for the day. On this towering trampoline-like platform, people dance around a central pole that pounds on a log mortar below. The ritual lasts from sunrise to sundown.

The communal celebration of the Holy Child or Santo Niño is just as elaborate. The residents of lbajay, Aklan, decorate their houses with seafood and carry bamboo poles displaying a wealth of sea harvest. They darken themselves like the Ati or Aeta and don extravagant costumes. In Kalibo, this costumed street-dancing and music making is a full-fledged carnival called ati-atihan. In Cebu, on the feast of the Santo Niño, civic, government, and religious organizations celebrate the sinulog to honor the Santo Niño aka Pit Senyor with dancing and votive candles before the basilica. In honor of the Holy Cross or Mahal na Poong Santa Cruz in Batangas, subli dancers perform under a large shed and before a tall crucifix. Women wearbalintawakand carry their hats like halos on their heads and in their hands; the men click bamboo castanets.

For some Spanish and Mexican social dances, especially the pandanggo and kuratsa, female participants wear the Tagalog balintawak or Visayanpatadyong. Dancers of the jota, polka, and habanera wear the Maria Clara costume, with itspanueloor shawl, fan, long necklace with tambourine-styled locket, and open shoes or slippers calledzapatillas. The men usually wear the barong tagalog or the Chinese-influenced collarlesscamisa de chinoand colored pants in the less Europeanized or the occupational dances.

From Spanish times to the present, the komedya, a play in verse with choreographed fighting, has been performed on improvised stages in town plazas. The audience stands around three sides of the stage. Thetelon,or painted backdrop and sets representing gardens, castle interiors and exteriors, and forests, established the setting for the scenes. Once adapted to formal theaters, the sets conformed to the requirements of the proscenium stage. Stages were lit by gas and later electric lamps. The komedya identified Christians and Muslims with different costumes and colors—for example, black or dark colors for the Christians and red for the Muslims.

The sarsuwela, a play in prose with songs and dances, was performed in formal theaters and proscenium stages, or in the outdoors on makeshiftentabladoor stage, open on three sides. A series of telon defined the setting for the scenes such as the facade of a rich person’s house, the interior of a poor person’s house, or the open field.

Bodabil continued the “realistic” backdrop trend. Casual European and American clothes went onstage. The Flapper Age transformed women’s clothing. With the advent of the Busby Berkeley musicals and Florenz Ziegfeld extravaganzas, platforms and ramps cramped local stages. Veladas (variety programs) and beauty contests started to change stage design. Art deco became fashionable and was exemplified by the Manila Metropolitan Theater, which was built in the 1930s.

The modern ballets of Trudl Dubsky-Zipper were first seen at the Metropolitan. Dubsky-Zipper employed scenic designers and designed the costumes herself. By this time, expressionism had tempered realism. Hans A. Heimann’s backdrops for Dubsky-Zipper’s Pictures at an Exhibition, 1940, for example, were emotionally laden. Ernest A. Komeld’s The Toy Box, 1940, featured a gigantic toy horse beside a realistic house. He also designed the stage for Dubsky-Zipper’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream, 1951, Anita Kane’s The Sleeping Beauty, 1953, and The Nutcracker, 1955, produced by Alexandra Danilova. Kane’s other set designers were Richard Abelardo for Mariang Makiling, 1939; Luis Esteban for Swan Lake, 1955; Juan Solomon for Mahjong, 1962; and Tony Stoner for The Nutcracker, 1965. Fernando Nicolas and Teodoro L. Hilado lit her shows.

Remedios de Oteyza’s productions were mostly designed by Milagros O. Villa-Abrille. For de Oteyza’s Hariraya Dance / Ballet Company, Arturo V. Cruz designed several sets and costumes, and Villa-Abrille and Nicolas, the lights.

Orosa-Goquingco’s Firebird, 1956, and The Clowns, 1957, had sets designed by Leandro Locsin, and later Arturo Cruz. Manuel Rodriguez created the set for her Noli Dance Suite, 1956. Nicolas, Siebe Hartendorp, and Benjamin Goquingco also designed lighting for her works. Ballet Philippines (BP) had sets designed by Locsin and Arturo Cruz who likewise created costumes for the company’s 24 works, including Amada and Itim Asu (Onyx Wolf), 1970; Juru-Pakal (The Enchanted Kris), 1971; Bungkos Suite (Bundle Suite) and Kapinangan, 1972; Ang Sultan (The Sultan), 1973; Mir-i-nisa, 1969; and Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 1, 1979.

Other early set designers for BP were Jose Joya, Ray Albano, Napoleon Abueva, Monino Duque, Roberto Chabet, Jaime de Guzman, Johnny Manahan, Toto Sicangco, Luis Layag, and Norman Walker. But it is resident set and costume designer Salvador Bernal who has seen BP through most of its grand classical ballets, and expressionistic modern dances. Some of his works are Baile de Ayer (Dance of Yesteryears), 1974; Images, 1975; Anak-Bulan (Moon Child), 1976; The Nutcracker, 1977; Swan Lake and Giselle Act II, 1979; Rama, Hari (Rama, King), La Lampara (The Lamp), 1980; Midsummer Night’s Dream, 1989; and Encantada (Enchantress), 1992.

In many ways Bernal’s prolific artistry helped BP gain its stature as a creator of dance theater. He understood stage space and provided not only decoration but also character and atmosphere which evoked a very particular time and place—whether reality or fantasy. In theater, Bernal’s depiction of reality transcended visual representation and thus enabled the audience to penetrate the imaginary world of the narrative.

The BP’s lighting designers include Teodoro Hilado, Monino Duque, Katsch S. J. Catoy, Roberto Roces, and Alex de Guzman. Catoy is one of BP’s notable lighting designers who did Rama, Hari and La Lampara, 1980; Giselle, 1982; Carmina Burana and Muybridge Frames, 1983; Romeo and Juliet and Carmen, 1984; Te Deum and Firebird, 1985; Nijinsky, 1987; and Siete Dolores (Seven Sorrows), 1988. As he closely attends to a narrative, he also intently listens to the music that a ballet uses. Recognizing the technical inadequacies in regional theaters, he wrote a booklet on how these can be lit in a simple and inexpensive way.

Dance Theatre Philippines (DTP) set designers include Pepe Roxas, German Lazo, Arturo Cruz, Johnny Hubilla, Rupert Acuña, Raquel Rey, Ferdie Jingco, and Aro Soriano. Among its costume designers are Marcella Lopez, Arturo Cruz, Eric Cruz, Robin Haig, Felicitas Layag-Radaic, Luis Layag, Basilio, and Raquel Rey. Lighting designers include Joonee Gamboa, Mitos Villareal, Monino Duque, Eduardo Castrillo, Raymond Salvacion, and Eric Cruz. Dance Concert Company set and costume designers include Arturo Cruz and Eric Cruz. Regular set designers for Manila Metropolis Ballet include Rollie de Leon, Mariflor Fajardo, Ferdie Jingco, Ben Payumo, Oscar Blanco, and Ray Albano. Its costume designers include Arturo Cruz, Fe Batungbakal, and Gang Gomez, while its lighting designers include Duque and Raymond Salvacion.

article.value: Designs for dance include the sets, properties, costumes, and lighting that create time and place; give a performance atmosphere; and provide symbols, allusions, and layers of meaning. The sets are painted or constructed. Properties or portable implements and costumes identify a character, occasion or action. Lighting may be natural or controlled with torches, candles, gas or electric lamps, spotlights, projections, and other equipment moved or modulated for effect.

Musical instruments like the Tagakaoloudol(plank drum) and the Kalingagangsalend purpose, properties, and accompaniment to the Tagakaolo and Kalinga dances, respectively. The elaboratekulintangstand withokirdesigns provides the setting for Maranao and Maguindanao dancing. The Bukidnon dance the dugso around an altar for their hinaklaran ritual as do the Manobo for their sangga ritual. Calledangkaw(bamboo platform) orsinengseng(a bamboo pole split at one end to support a plate or candle) by the Manobo, these altars are decorated withmenhaw(coconut fronds) and hold offerings of rice, buyo, betel nut, lime, raw eggs, and glasses of water. During the sangga, which addresses coastal spirits, the dancers also offer cigarettes, wine, cookies, and rice cakes. In the pagdiwata of the Tagbanwa in Palawan, elaborate bamboo altars in and outside the house also bear offerings. Thebaylanor shaman, covered by a mysteriousalindugan(a large black hood), sits on a swing, and offers the spirits, among other things, a votive bird, rice wine, rice cakes, and jewelry laid out on a mat. On this towering trampoline-like platform, people dance around a central pole that pounds on a log mortar below. The ritual lasts from sunrise to sundown.

The communal celebration of the Holy Child or Santo Niño is just as elaborate. In Kalibo, this costumed street-dancing and music making is a full-fledged carnival called ati-atihan.
