From Spanish times to the present, the komedya, a play in verse with choreographed fighting, has been performed on improvised stages in town plazas. description: Topics related to dance creation and performance
text:
Dance education is the transmission of the traditions, techniques, and styles of dance from one generation to the next. Tradition means the total practice of the art in the context of its history and culture. Technique is the skill with which the vocabulary of dance is expressed. Tradition and technique involve accompaniment, costuming, time, place, and purpose or occasion. Style is refined technique and applied tradition. Tradition, technique, and style may be taught formally at a dance academy, or informally through simple instruction and coaching. A dancer may adopt ideas and techniques encountered in diverse ways.

Ritual dances are learned as part of communal life in the Philippines. While shamans may lead and direct them, they are shared and easily learned by assistants or the community. In many areas, the priest/priestess (mambunong, mumbaki,andmandadawakin northern Philippines, orbabaylanin the south) may have an assistant who learns the complete ritual processes. In the Subanon buklog, the whole community builds the traditional bamboo structure and executes dance movements in a circle as they offer prayers to the gods. In Christianized areas, the ritual dances may be taught by elders, as in Batangas, where the subli and thepanata(pledge) that goes with it are taught formally. But in many areas, people simply join a gathering, executing the simple and repetitive movements of popular festivals like the pandangguhan in Obando, Bulacan; the turumba in Pakil, Laguna; the ati-atihan in Kalibo, Aklan; or the sinulog in Cebu or Bohol.

Folk dances are learned by the community through constant exposure to these performances. Mimetic and occupation dances are transmutations of what people see and do, so that the motives behind and the forms of the dances derive from everyday life. Social dances—from game and song dances to courtship and wedding dances—are so familiar to the community that everyone is expected to execute them at social functions.When Philippine and foreign folk dances became an important part of the educational system after Francisca Reyes-Aquino’s research became nationally known in the 1930s, they were taught in schools and performed in field demonstrations, staged programs, and town fiestas. Physical education teachers joined annual summer training programs or workshops. Young men and women joined folk dance troupes, some of which turned professional and toured nationally and internationally.

When ballet schools were established in Manila in the 1920s, Kay Williams and Luva Adameit were among the first teachers to teach students the movements of the European dance form. From Adameit’s Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School came the first Filipino ballet dancers, such as Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Remedios de Oteyza, and Rosalia Merino-Santos, who later became professional teachers and choreographers.

Ballet dancers train from 8 to 10 years in established institutions. A child starts at 7 or 10 years old, and graduates at 16 or 18. The training begins similarly for both boys and girls, but gradually becomes separate according to technical and aesthetic differences. Both sexes take a partnering ( pas de deux or double work) class to learn the turns or lifts. Repertoire classes introduce them to the classics.

Over the years, many ballet schools in the Philippines adopted established syllabi practiced and examined worldwide. The first one was the Royal Academy of Dancing, started here by Felicitas Layag-Radaic. In 2015, there are other syllabi taught, among them, those of the Australian Conservatoire of Ballet, the Commonwealth Society of Teachers of Dancing from Australia, the Vaganova from Russia, and the Cecchetti Society. Layag-Radaic, in collaboration with Noordin Jumalon and Vella Damian, founded the Philippine National Ballet Syllabus that covers eight grades and matches international levels.

Formal dance training usually starts in studio-schools privately owned by their respective teachers, as exemplified by Anita Kane’s School of Classical Dance, Remedios de Oteyza’s Ballet and Dance Center, and Ricardo and Roberta Cassell’s Studio Dance School. Due to a ballet ban issued by the Catholic Church hierarchy in the 1950s, the Studio Dance Group ended when the Cassells returned to the United States. Writing on the church’s injunction, Fr Antonio Piñon explains that the ban was a consensus among schools run by nuns, and then “approved and endorsed by the Hierarchy.” Later in the 1970s, dance in liturgy was taught in Silliman University in Dumaguete, while a similar course became part of the curriculum at the Asian Institute of Liturgical Music in Quezon City.

Despite the ballet ban, many dancers kept their own ballet schools, which flourished in the decades after the 1950s. Among these were Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Rosalia Merino-Santos, Sony Lopez-Gonzalez, Joji Felix-Velarde with Eddie Elejar and Cesar Mendoza, Layag-Radaic, Julie Borromeo, and Vella Damian. Notable in the regions were Fe Sala Villarica (whose school was later run by Nicolas Pacaña and Gregory Aaron), Elsie and Pancho Uytiepo, and Carmen Dakudao-Locsin. In 1970, the first Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Summer Dance Workshop led to the founding of the CCP Dance School. Today there are many studio-schools nationwide.

In 1976 the ballet schools formed the Ballet Federation of the Philippines (BFP) that ran festivals and its own publications. Today many of these groups constitute the Association of Ballet Academies Philippines (ABAP), which was founded by Vella Damian and close associates. Some of these ballet schools link themselves and conduct examinations according to the various syllabi systems mentioned above. ABAP and other networks also conduct ballet competitions. On a higher level and linked to the Department of Education, the National Music Competition of Young Artists (NAMCYA) ran a national ballet competition for eight years up to 2012. In 2014, the CCP took over.

In modern dance, different technical and aesthetic demands prevail. Because modern dance emerged in the 20th century under individual initiatives, there are various techniques and styles, like those of Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey, Charles Weidman, Jose Limon, and Merce Cunningham. Other styles, such as those of Isadora Duncan and Mary Wigman, did not become as popular. These new styles were influenced by anthropological, psychological, and aesthetic studies, and advances in modern science and art. For example, they emphasize varied physical dynamics, rootedness in going to the ground or floor, and improvisational and compositional approaches in structuring a dance class. At the same time, each style or technique serves the theme or method of its founder or choreographer.

Modern dance first came to the Philippines in the 1930s by way of two Austrians, namely Kaethe Hauser and Trudl Dubsky-Zipper. The first to come, Hauser, taught children of the elite, among them Maribel Aboitiz. With other and later teachers, Aboitiz became Manila’s stellar ballerina. Identified with the European Austruckstanz (Expressive Dance), Dubsky-Zipper first taught at the UP Conservatory of Music. Her educational influence is seen in Carmen Adevoso, Adina Rigor-Ferrer, Remedios Villanueva-Piñon, Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, and Rosalia Merino-Santos. In the 1970s, Shona MacTavish taught in the Austruckstanz style of Gertrude Bondeweiser (Dubsky-Zipper’s teacher) in Silliman University. A globally pivotal dancer-choreographer was Mary Wigman who studied with Rudolf von Laban and Jacques Dalcroze. Dalcroze’s Eurythmics is taught to dancers and musicians in UP College of Music. Wigman has some influence in the Philippines through Merino-Santos who studied with her in Europe, Alice Reyes whose teacher was Hanya Holm from Wigman’s school, and through Wigman-exponent Kazuo Kamizawa who briefly taught for the UP’s dance degree program.

In the 1980s, newer approaches came with Release Technique, Contact Improvisation, Labanalysis, the techniques of Pilates, Alexander, Feldenkrais, Grotowski, and Physical Theater that lend themselves to choreographic exploration or serve physical conditioning and rehabilitation. Visiting Fulbright fellow Kristin Jackson taught Irene Dowd’s method and her own style at UP and Ballet Philippines. Jackson’s dancing bloomed in the phase of postmodernism, particularly while dancing with Laura Dean, and in her own choreographies. This movement undermined “traditional” modern dance (Graham, Humphrey, Holm, Limon, et al.) by its diverse conceptions of time and space, themes, and textures. Similarly, new orientation in anthropology as seen in Alfred Gell’s study of Umeda dance in Papua New Guinea or the ethnographic analysis of the visual arts like that in Abraham Sakili’s study of Philippine Muslim society may be linked to creative modes in choreography and movement notation.

Dance was formally taught in school as part of academic curricula in the 1950s through the efforts of Francisca Reyes-Aquino. But over the years, the teaching of dance has changed. Where previously the primary grades and high schools taught music and the arts separately, the Department of Education (DepEd, 1987–2001), formerly known as the Ministry of Education, Culture, and Sports, combined both of these with fitness and sports. The program has been called Physical Education, Health, and Music (PEHM), or Music, Arts, and Physical Education (MAPE). Expertise in all these areas is not generally available, so DepEd holds supplementary summer seminars. Exemplary is the dance at the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) in Los Baños. It has both ballet and folk dance majors, with their respective performing groups. For projects, they collaborate with music, theater, and visual arts majors. In the past years, other public high schools also set up their own Special Program from the Arts now found in the regions.

The dance degree was eventually institutionalized in the collegiate level. The first degree course was instituted in 1972 at the Philippine Women’s University where it stayed for a while to graduate a few with a Bachelor in Music Major in Dance.

At the University of the Philippines (UP), the College of Sports, Physical Education, and Recreation (SPEAR) started a certificate program in 1981. After SPEAR was renamed the College of Human Kinetics, this program was replaced with a Bachelor of Sports Science in 2002 without a dance degree offering. In 2015, its master of science in human movement science had a major in physical education with electives and thesis in dance. Also in 1981, the UP College of Music (UPCMu) started to offer a four-year Diploma in Performing Arts Major in Dance. Later, the UPCMu provided an option for a five-year Bachelor of Music, Major in Dance. Courses are in dance technique (ballet, modern dance, Filipino and Asian dance), dance theory, dance composition, recital production, music, and theater. Solely in the Philippines, the program includes movement notation—to train students to read, write, and stage dances from scores. Dancers collaborate with music majors in compositional endeavors. They also have the option to join the UP Dance Company, or even Ballet Philippines (BP) or Philippine Ballet Theatre.

In 1995, the La Salle-St. Benilde College started to offer a Bachelor in Performing Arts, Major in Dance in consortium with the Ballet Philippines Dance School at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dance majors collaborate with those in other art productions. Some dance requirements like training and performing are worked out with BP. At the same time Benilde has its own Romancon Dance Company with its own repertoire. In other schools, the dance is mainly placed in the physical education program, where it has been the longest in the academic world. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

In the 1980s, newer approaches came with Release Technique, Contact Improvisation, Labanalysis, the techniques of Pilates, Alexander, Feldenkrais, Grotowski, and Physical Theater that lend themselves to choreographic exploration or serve physical conditioning and rehabilitation. Visiting Fulbright fellow Kristin Jackson taught Irene Dowd’s method and her own style at UP and Ballet Philippines. Jackson’s dancing bloomed in the phase of postmodernism, particularly while dancing with Laura Dean, and in her own choreographies. This movement undermined “traditional” modern dance (Graham, Humphrey, Holm, Limon, et al.) by its diverse conceptions of time and space, themes, and textures. Similarly, new orientation in anthropology as seen in Alfred Gell’s study of Umeda dance in Papua New Guinea or the ethnographic analysis of the visual arts like that in Abraham Sakili’s study of Philippine Muslim society may be linked to creative modes in choreography and movement notation.

Dance was formally taught in school as part of academic curricula in the 1950s through the efforts of Francisca Reyes-Aquino. But over the years, the teaching of dance has changed. Where previously the primary grades and high schools taught music and the arts separately, the Department of Education (DepEd, 1987–2001), formerly known as the Ministry of Education, Culture, and Sports, combined both of these with fitness and sports. The program has been called Physical Education, Health, and Music (PEHM), or Music, Arts, and Physical Education (MAPE). Expertise in all these areas is not generally available, so DepEd holds supplementary summer seminars. Exemplary is the dance at the Philippine High School for the Arts (PHSA) in Los Baños. It has both ballet and folk dance majors, with their respective performing groups. For projects, they collaborate with music, theater, and visual arts majors. In the past years, other public high schools also set up their own Special Program from the Arts now found in the regions.

The dance degree was eventually institutionalized in the collegiate level. The first degree course was instituted in 1972 at the Philippine Women’s University where it stayed for a while to graduate a few with a Bachelor in Music Major in Dance.

At the University of the Philippines (UP), the College of Sports, Physical Education, and Recreation (SPEAR) started a certificate program in 1981. After SPEAR was renamed the College of Human Kinetics, this program was replaced with a Bachelor of Sports Science in 2002 without a dance degree offering. In 2015, its master of science in human movement science had a major in physical education with electives and thesis in dance. Also in 1981, the UP College of Music (UPCMu) started to offer a four-year Diploma in Performing Arts Major in Dance. Later, the UPCMu provided an option for a five-year Bachelor of Music, Major in Dance. Courses are in dance technique (ballet, modern dance, Filipino and Asian dance), dance theory, dance composition, recital production, music, and theater. Solely in the Philippines, the program includes movement notation—to train students to read, write, and stage dances from scores. Dancers collaborate with music majors in compositional endeavors. They also have the option to join the UP Dance Company, or even Ballet Philippines (BP) or Philippine Ballet Theatre.

In 1995, the La Salle-St. Benilde College started to offer a Bachelor in Performing Arts, Major in Dance in consortium with the Ballet Philippines Dance School at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Dance majors collaborate with those in other art productions. Some dance requirements like training and performing are worked out with BP. At the same time Benilde has its own Romancon Dance Company with its own repertoire. In other schools, the dance is mainly placed in the physical education program, where it has been the longest in the academic world.
Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

Dance is almost always accompanied by music. The accompanying sound may be simple or complex, supplied by the dancer herself/himself or by nondancing singers and/or instrumentalists. Music supplied by the dance includes stamping, snapping of fingers, body slapping, or singing. This may be extended by the use of bells, castanets, shells, sticks, boots, tambourines, cymbals, or drums hung on the dancer’s body. Dance music has a wide range. There may be only one accompanist or a whole orchestra; the music may be improvised or composed.

Indigenous music and dance in the Philippines are as richly varied and diverse as the cultures from which they emanate. There are over 50 ethnolinguistic groups scattered throughout the Philippines. Dance and its music are part of rituals that commemorate various tribal life activities such as courtship, marriage, death, birth, healing, welcome, thanksgiving, victory in war, planting, or harvesting.

Among the Kalinga, gong playing is an integral part of peace pact gatherings, weddings, prestige ceremonies or feasts in celebration of important events. Men performing in the gangsa palook style beat gongs with a stick as they stand beside each other in one line executing alternate steps, at first without moving from their place. Gradually, the man at the end of the line moves away in a stooping position followed by the others, forming a circle and continually moving in a long, curved line while alternately stooping and straightening up. The gongs are held in the left hand, away from the body, then near the body. Normally, sixgangsaor flat gongsare used. The music consists of two rhythms—dadawandsapi—played in opposition to each other. The alternating beats of these two rhythms are interspersed with beats emanating from the four other gongs. Though women may join in the dance, only men perform on the gongs.

The tadek, danced by a male and female, is accompanied by six gongs played intopayyastyle, in which the gongs are hit with the hands with tapping and sliding motions. The first four gongs play identical rhythms, one beat behind each other. The fifth gong sounds an ostinato rhythm of deadened tones, while the sixth gong sounds a fast tapping rhythm.

Other flat gong ensembles with dance are found in the Cordilleras of northern Luzon. The Ifugao use a three-gong ensemble—tobop,hibat, andahot— to accompany men dancing in a ceremony to celebrate a harvest. Karao men use seven gongs struck with sticks, each with its own rhythm, while the women dance the itundak and tinebtebak. In Bontoc, men dance and play a set of 10 gongs. Thealiwengandsoklungangongs play opposing rhythms in different tambours interspersed with rhythms played on the eight remainingkalos(gongs).

The Ifugao execute the himong ritual for deaths caused by foul play. Men play thebangibang(struck wooden sticks) while dancing in line. An alternation of strokes between odd- and even-numbered men in the line produces a regular rhythm of light and heavy sounds.

The Tagakaolo women of Davao del Sur execute a dance imitating thetamialabird. Wearing belts and anklets ofcascabels, the dancers move to the music of theudol, a hollowed-out log drum. Two performers beat the top of the log drum. One is seated, striking the log drum with twopatawagay(short sticks), while the second moves freely around the instrument, striking the log drum with anutumay(long, thin stick), beating a rhythmic pattern in counterpoint to that of the patawagay.

The Matigsalug of Bukidnon have a charming courting dance performed by a male while playing thekudlong(two-stringed lute) and singing. The woman plucks hertakumbo(bamboo zither), dancing around the man who eventually follows behind her in small mincing steps.

The Maguindanao musicians play thekulintang, a set of eight graduated bossed gongs, and thedabakan(drum) to accompany the dancing of the medium during thepagibat, a curing rite.

The Manobokulintanganis made up of six to ten graduated bossed gongs suspended from a frame in pyramid fashion, with the highest-pitched gong on top and the lowest at the bottom. A melody player strikes the various gongs using one beater, while a drone player strikes a continuously repeated pattern on the lowest pitched gong. The ensemble is completed by a third musician beating on a cylindrical wooden drum. The gong melody player leaves the instrument occasionally to participate in the dance. The music and dance are performed during festive gatherings such as weddings.

Among the Tausug of Jolo, dancing occurs primarily as an adjunct to the kulintangan, a gong ensemble consisting of a set of 8 (in Pata island) to 11 (in Luuk) bossed gongs laid in a row, atunggalan(single, large bossed gong),duahan(a set of two-paired bossed gongs), and twogandang(drums). Dancing is done only for entertainment, with no religious or social function. Gong music consists of a series of three types of compositions : sinug,kuliri, andlubak-lubak, the latter being played as accompaniment to the dancer.

The gong ensemble of the Sama Dilaut (Badjao) of Sitangkai is similar to that of the Tausug, consisting of a seven to nine-piece kulintangan, three hanging gongs calledbua,pulakan, andtamuk, and atambulor drum. Gong music is associated with dance and is performed on important social occasions such as marriage ormagkawin, circumcision ormagislam, and communication with spirits ormagigal jin. Often, dancers add the clicking sound of theirbula bula(wooden castanets) to the instrumental ensemble. Different tunes are encountered: titik tagunggu (ceremonial voyage, marriage, circumcision); titik tabawan (wedding, dance of possession); tariray or limbayan (festive occasions danced by younger women characterized by suggestive shoulder jerks and gyrating torsos); and titik jin and lellang (dances of mediums).

Stamp dancing to the fast beat ofagung(gongs) by Hanunuo men and boys is an expression of jubilation during thepanludan, a feast with merrymaking. Many other instruments like guitars, fiddles, flutes, mouth harps, zithers, and whistles join thekalipay(noise making).

In Bataan, the Aeta commemorate weddings with the ambahan, which lasts for several days. Participants dance—hopping, stepping, and kicking up their heels—to the accompaniment ofpalai(gong) beats, in an oval around a bonfire, while singingamba(verses) in leader-chorus style.

The dances among lowland Christian groups form the greatest bulk of “popular” folk dances. Though some dances like the kumintang retain indigenous forms and traditions, the great majority has been strongly influenced by turn-of-the-century European ballroom dances as well as Spanish and Mexican national dances. Thus, they have such names as habanera, tango, pandanggo, seguidilla, jota, kuratsa, polka, mazurka, danza, wultz, and rigodon.

The Castilian and Andalusian courtship dance, fandango, came to be known locally as the pandanggo. Upon adaptation, its triple-time rhythm and moderately fast waltz-like tempo were retained. Travelogues by Guignes, 1808, Lafond, 1884, and Mallat, 1846, mention the fandango being performed for the entertainment of the elite at balls and soirees. Although Mallat mentions the fandango being accompanied quite dexterously by castanets, Walls y Merino, 1892, specifically cites the guitar and thebajo de unas(string bass) as the usual accompaniment.

As the pandanggo spread to various Philippine regions, each locality evolved its own characteristic movements and accessories. Thus, the llocano pandanggo of Camiling, Tarlac, and the Visayan pandanggo retain the pantomimic character of the Spanish prototype in which the men use a hat when inviting a chosen maiden to be a dance partner. Instead of the hat, lighted oil lamps may also be used. Both the Ilocano and Visayan pandanggo use music with only one part (A) repeated. However, the pandanggo sa ilaw, whose musical accompaniment was composed by Antonino Buenaventura using the original rhthym found in Mindoro, is tripartite (ABC), the sections occurring twice and ending with a repeated last section, thus: ABCABCCC.

Originally from Aragon, Spain, the jota was indispensable at provincial fiestas, particularly those organized in honor of visiting civil and religious dignitaries. Jotas are found in almost every locality, some examples of which are the jota filipina of Lal-lo, Cagayan; the jota paloana of Palo, Leyte; the jota vintarina of Vintar, Ilocos Norte; the jota yogad of Echague, Isabela; and the jota batangueña of Batangas. Music is variously repeated, and comprises three to six sections. It is in rapid triple time quite similar to that of the pandanggo.

Another dance in triple time is the kuratsa. Its music is quicker and livelier than the jota or the pandanggo. It is characterized by running 16th-note figures accompanied by a repeated rhythmic accompaniment consisting of two quarter notes followed by two eighth notes. At town fiestas, the kuratsa was played by an ensemble consisting of a clarinet and two trombones.

The Cuban habanerain duple time is in a slow or moderate tempo. The later danza and tango were outgrowths of the habanera, retaining the latter’s rhythmic characteristics. Dances utilizing the habanera rhythms may or may not be titled as habaneras. Examples are the mascota of Cauayan, Isabela; the imbestida of Bayombong, Nueva Viscaya; the annafunan of Cagayan; the sainita of Nueva Viscaya; and the habanera of Ilocos Sur. Many composers wrote music in the habanera style, e.g., Nicanor Abelardo’s “Bituing Marikit” (Beautiful Star), Dolores Paterno’s “La Flor de Manila” (The Flower of Manila) also known as “Sampaguita,” and J. Massaguer’s “La Bella Filipina” (The Beautiful Filipina).

Other favorite ballroom dances which found their way to the Philippines were the polka, mazurka, and waltz or balse. The polka, which is of Bohemian origin, has a fast duple rhythm, as in the polka sala of Mindoro and the polkabal of Tayabas. The Polish mazurka is in triple meter and may be performed at several speeds from moderately slow to very fast. The waltz or balse continues to be popular until today. Its moderate triple time is used for a great number of dances other than the balse itself.

The music for most of these European-type dances is homophonic and harmonized in the major-minor tonal system. Most of the music is in 3/4 time with some 2/4 (habanera), 4/4, and fewer in 6/8 or 12/8 (quadrille) rhythms. Many of the melodies start with an upbeat. The melodies are cast in strictly phrased 8-measure periods (a 4-measure antecedent phrase followed by a 4-measure consequent phrase) or 16-measure double periods. The music is sectionalized, the number of sections varying from two to eight or more. The sections are repeated variously, e.g., ABB, ABAB, ABACAB, etc. Occasionally, there is a metric change in the sections, or a change from major to minor tonality or vice versa. Very often, the dance opens with a short two-measure introduction.

Dances are accompanied by whatever instruments are available. Bands and orchestras used to accompany the dances at balls and soirees in the second half of the 19th century. Today, in many grade and high schools where these dances are taught, the music is played on the piano. In the absence of a piano, a guitar or guitars are used. Therondalla, an ensemble of plucked chordophones, is the favorite accompanying instrumental group. Originally, the rondalla was known as thecomparza. It reached its height of popularity during the later period of the Spanish regime and the early years of the American era. In the 1990s interest in the rondalla was revived and many schools now have rondalla groups. A small ensemble consists of one or twobandurria, a guitar, a laud, an octavina and a bass guitar, also known as the bajo de unas or a string bass.

Relatively young is Philippine professional theatrical dancing or ballet. Filipino artists and audiences began showing an interest in this art form in the 1930s. Enthusiasm for ballet grew steadily in the ensuing decades. Since the 1970s, about 100 works have been choreographed to music by Filipino composers. Approximately half of these works were original ballets, many commissioned jointly by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the League of Filipino Composers (LFC) for Ballet Philippines (BP). The remaining half were works adapted from set music.

Ballets for which original music was composed are in a variety of styles; the light and popular in Rama, Hari (Rama, the King), 1983, by Ryan Cayabyab and Tales of the Manuvu, 1977, by Nonong Pedero; the atonal neoromantic in Mir-i-nisa, 1969, by Eliseo Pajaro; the avant-garde in Yerma, 1982,by Francisco Feliciano; the romantic in Ang Konsierto (The Concert), 1994, by Hilarion Rubio; the electronic in Muybridge Frames, 1983, by Fabian Obispo; the eclectic in Camille and Gitana by Jeffrey Ching; the multimedia and experimental in Awit (Song), 1982, and Ta-o (Man Dissected) 1980, by Ramon Santos. Lucrecia R. Kasilag’s music has been used for many dances of the CCP Dance Company (later Ballet Philippines), among them Amada, 1970, Ang Sultan (The Sultan), 1973, Tapestry, 1983, and Kulam (Witchcraft), 1986. These pieces were performed by a full Western orchestra.

Choreographers also used previously composed works by Filipinos for ballets, like Lucrecia Kasilag’s Fantasie on a Four-note Theme, for Rosalia Merino-Santos’s Of Cocks and Kings, 1958; Jose Maceda’s Agungan, Ugma-ugma and Kubing, for Eddie Elejar’s Juru-Pakal (The Enchanted Kris), 1971; Ramon Santos’s Ding Ding nga Diyawa, for Alice Reyes’s Dugso, 1972; Ryan Cayabyab’s One, for Antonio Fabella’s Limang Dipa (Five Armstretches), 1981, and Misa (Mass), for Basilio’s Misa Filipina (Filipino Mass), 1984; and Nicanor Abelardo’s Sinfonietta for Strings, for Basilio’s Exultations, 1984.

Aside from the standard classic ballet repertoire—Tchaikovsky’s Swan Lake, Nutcracker Suite, Sleeping Beauty; Bizet’s Carmen; Glasunov’s Raymonda Variations; Prokofiev’s Romeo and Juliet; Minkus’s Don Quixote; and Adam’s Giselle —are works based on set music representing a wide gamut of styles. Music in the romantic style was favored: Mendelssohn for A Midsummer Night’s Dream by Trudl Dubsky-Zipper, 1951, Alice Reyes, 1976, and Edna Vida, 1989; Chopin for Fabella’s Invitation, 1977, and Felicitas Layag-Radaic’s La Innamorata, 1983; Tchaikovsky for Remedios de Oteyza’s Concerto, 1982; Dohnanyi for de Oteyza’s Haunted Ballroom,1973; and Johann Strauss for Fabella’s Graduation Ball, 1986.

The baroque music by Johann Sebastian Bach was used for Alice Reyes’s Company, 1970; Layag-de los Reyes’s Bach in Blue, 1981; and Basilio’s Votive Dance, 1986. Antonio Vivaldi was used for Eric Cruz’s Visions in Blue and Basilio’s Mosque Baroque, 1975; while Johann Pachelbel was used for Basilio’s Canon of Life, 1984, and Nonoy Froilan’s One Afternoon, 1987.

Taken from the Classic period are Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart’s music used in Basilio’s Crystal Concerto, 1983, and Fabella’s Entrances and Exits, 1980; and Franz Schubert’s used in Basilio’s Salutations, 1981. Twentieth-century works, both popular and avant-garde were also chosen. In the popular vein are Lonely Hearts Club Band by Alice Reyes, 1977, to Lennon and McCartney; and Vermillion Scarf by Gener Caringal, 1982, to the Beatles. The early and mid-20th century music include works by Paul Hindemith for Eddie Elejar’s Jewels, 1970; Kazuo Fukushima for Luis Layag’s The Warriors, 1970; Benjamin Britten for Fabella’s Prince of the Pagodas, 1972; Leonard Bernstein for Alice Reyes’s Chichester Psalms, 1973; Carl Orff for Alice Reyes’s Carmina Burana, 1975; Lucas Foss for Denisa Reyes’s Arem, 1975; Bela Bartok for Basilio’s Testament, 1980; Toru Takernitsu for Eddie Elejar’s Iago, 1986, and Conrad Dy-Liacco’s Tat Gubat; Philip Glass for Agnes Locsin’s Moriones, 1987; and John Cage for Paul Ocampo’s Konamiras.

The recent accessibility of recordings and Internet downloadings has modified how choreographers, dancers, and audiences attune themselves to music. They have widened their listening repertoire from the East and West, thus enriching the styles and textures of their works. However, the breadth of choice sometimes leads to lack of discrimination. One easy temptation is that choreographers no longer avail of advice, musical scores, or accompaniment from musicians. Their wide choice includes Filipino and foreign composers from collection—recordings that may result in a hodgepodge of musical and choreographic styles. Moreover, composers are not always consulted about the use of their music.

In the UP College of Music, there are composers and instrumentalists who provide music for dance, like Ramon Santos, Josefino Toledo, Jonas Baes, Verne de la Peña, Christine Muyco, and the college’s several performing groups. Dancers collaborate with composers in UPConemus (Composers for New Music). Young composers who have done music for full ballets are Jesse Lucas for BP’s Darna; Jerrold Tarog for BP’s After Whom; Jed Balsamo for BP’s Crisostomo Ibarra;Teresa Barrozo for the Philippine High School for the Arts’ Sulog sa Kinabuhi (Surge in Life) and the UP Dance Company’s (UPDC) Pavillion 4 and Mata sa Damgo (Eye in Dream);and Toni Muñoz, also for UPDC’s Nasalapu-an (Birthing)and Flight. With very rare chances to repeat a dance, their original music may still live on in concert form or in new choreographed versions. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

At town fiestas, the kuratsa was played by an ensemble consisting of a clarinet and two trombones.

The Cuban habanerain duple time is in a slow or moderate tempo. The later danza and tango were outgrowths of the habanera, retaining the latter’s rhythmic characteristics. Dances utilizing the habanera rhythms may or may not be titled as habaneras. Examples are the mascota of Cauayan, Isabela; the imbestida of Bayombong, Nueva Viscaya; the annafunan of Cagayan; the sainita of Nueva Viscaya; and the habanera of Ilocos Sur. Many composers wrote music in the habanera style, e.g., Nicanor Abelardo’s “Bituing Marikit” (Beautiful Star), Dolores Paterno’s “La Flor de Manila” (The Flower of Manila) also known as “Sampaguita,” and J. Massaguer’s “La Bella Filipina” (The Beautiful Filipina).

Other favorite ballroom dances which found their way to the Philippines were the polka, mazurka, and waltz or balse. The polka, which is of Bohemian origin, has a fast duple rhythm, as in the polka sala of Mindoro and the polkabal of Tayabas. The Polish mazurka is in triple meter and may be performed at several speeds from moderately slow to very fast. The waltz or balse continues to be popular until today. Its moderate triple time is used for a great number of dances other than the balse itself.

The music for most of these European-type dances is homophonic and harmonized in the major-minor tonal system. Most of the music is in 3/4 time with some 2/4 (habanera), 4/4, and fewer in 6/8 or 12/8 (quadrille) rhythms. Many of the melodies start with an upbeat. The melodies are cast in strictly phrased 8-measure periods (a 4-measure antecedent phrase followed by a 4-measure consequent phrase) or 16-measure double periods. The music is sectionalized, the number of sections varying from two to eight or more. The sections are repeated variously, e.g., ABB, ABAB, ABACAB, etc. Occasionally, there is a metric change in the sections, or a change from major to minor tonality or vice versa. Very often, the dance opens with a short two-measure introduction.

Dances are accompanied by whatever instruments are available. Bands and orchestras used to accompany the dances at balls and soirees in the second half of the 19th century. Today, in many grade and high schools where these dances are taught, the music is played on the piano. In the absence of a piano, a guitar or guitars are used. Therondalla, an ensemble of plucked chordophones, is the favorite accompanying instrumental group. Originally, the rondalla was known as thecomparza. It reached its height of popularity during the later period of the Spanish regime and the early years of the American era. In the 1990s interest in the rondalla was revived and many schools now have rondalla groups. A small ensemble consists of one or twobandurria, a guitar, a laud, an octavina and a bass guitar, also known as the bajo de unas or a string bass.

Relatively young is Philippine professional theatrical dancing or ballet. Filipino artists and audiences began showing an interest in this art form in the 1930s. Enthusiasm for ballet grew steadily in the ensuing decades. Since the 1970s, about 100 works have been choreographed to music by Filipino composers. Approximately half of these works were original ballets, many commissioned jointly by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and the League of Filipino Composers (LFC) for Ballet Philippines (BP). The remaining half were works adapted from set music.

Ballets for which original music was composed are in a variety of styles; the light and popular in Rama, Hari (Rama, the King), 1983, by Ryan Cayabyab and Tales of the Manuvu, 1977, by Nonong Pedero; the atonal neoromantic in Mir-i-nisa, 1969, by Eliseo Pajaro; the avant-garde in Yerma, 1982,by Francisco Feliciano; the romantic in Ang Konsierto (The Concert), 1994, by Hilarion Rubio; the electronic in Muybridge Frames, 1983, by Fabian Obispo; the eclectic in Camille and Gitana by Jeffrey Ching; the multimedia and experimental in Awit (Song), 1982, and Ta-o (Man Dissected) 1980, by Ramon Santos. Lucrecia R. Kasilag’s music has been used for many dances of the CCP Dance Company (later Ballet Philippines), among them Amada, 1970, Ang Sultan (The Sultan), 1973, Tapestry, 1983, and Kulam (Witchcraft), 1986. These pieces were performed by a full Western orchestra.

Choreographers also used previously composed works by Filipinos for ballets, like Lucrecia Kasilag’s Fantasie on a Four-note Theme, for Rosalia Merino-Santos’s Of Cocks and Kings, 1958; Jose Maceda’s Agungan, Ugma-ugma and Kubing, for Eddie Elejar’s Juru-Pakal (The Enchanted Kris), 1971; Ramon Santos’s Ding Ding nga Diyawa, for Alice Reyes’s Dugso, 1972; Ryan Cayabyab’s One, for Antonio Fabella’s Limang Dipa (Five Armstretches), 1981, and Misa (Mass), for Basilio’s Misa Filipina (Filipino Mass), 1984; and Nicanor Abelardo’s Sinfonietta for Strings, for Basilio’s Exultations, 1984.

Aside from the standard classic ballet repertoire—Tchaikovsky’s Swan Lake, Nutcracker Suite, Sleeping Beauty; Bizet’s Carmen; Glasunov’s Raymonda Variations; Prokofiev’s Romeo and Juliet; Minkus’s Don Quixote; and Adam’s Giselle —are works based on set music representing a wide gamut of styles. Music in the romantic style was favored: Mendelssohn for A Midsummer Night’s Dream by Trudl Dubsky-Zipper, 1951, Alice Reyes, 1976, and Edna Vida, 1989; Chopin for Fabella’s Invitation, 1977, and Felicitas Layag-Radaic’s La Innamorata, 1983; Tchaikovsky for Remedios de Oteyza’s Concerto, 1982; Dohnanyi for de Oteyza’s Haunted Ballroom,1973; and Johann Strauss for Fabella’s Graduation Ball, 1986.

The baroque music by Johann Sebastian Bach was used for Alice Reyes’s Company, 1970; Layag-de los Reyes’s Bach in Blue, 1981; and Basilio’s Votive Dance, 1986. Antonio Vivaldi was used for Eric Cruz’s Visions in Blue and Basilio’s Mosque Baroque, 1975; while Johann Pachelbel was used for Basilio’s Canon of Life, 1984, and Nonoy Froilan’s One Afternoon, 1987.

Taken from the Classic period are Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart’s music used in Basilio’s Crystal Concerto, 1983, and Fabella’s Entrances and Exits, 1980; and Franz Schubert’s used in Basilio’s Salutations, 1981. Twentieth-century works, both popular and avant-garde were also chosen. In the popular vein are Lonely Hearts Club Band by Alice Reyes, 1977, to Lennon and McCartney; and Vermillion Scarf by Gener Caringal, 1982, to the Beatles. The early and mid-20th century music include works by Paul Hindemith for Eddie Elejar’s Jewels, 1970; Kazuo Fukushima for Luis Layag’s The Warriors, 1970; Benjamin Britten for Fabella’s Prince of the Pagodas, 1972; Leonard Bernstein for Alice Reyes’s Chichester Psalms, 1973; Carl Orff for Alice Reyes’s Carmina Burana, 1975; Lucas Foss for Denisa Reyes’s Arem, 1975; Bela Bartok for Basilio’s Testament, 1980; Toru Takernitsu for Eddie Elejar’s Iago, 1986, and Conrad Dy-Liacco’s Tat Gubat; Philip Glass for Agnes Locsin’s Moriones, 1987; and John Cage for Paul Ocampo’s Konamiras.

The recent accessibility of recordings and Internet downloadings has modified how choreographers, dancers, and audiences attune themselves to music. They have widened their listening repertoire from the East and West, thus enriching the styles and textures of their works. However, the breadth of choice sometimes leads to lack of discrimination. One easy temptation is that choreographers no longer avail of advice, musical scores, or accompaniment from musicians. Their wide choice includes Filipino and foreign composers from collection—recordings that may result in a hodgepodge of musical and choreographic styles. Moreover, composers are not always consulted about the use of their music.

In the UP College of Music, there are composers and instrumentalists who provide music for dance, like Ramon Santos, Josefino Toledo, Jonas Baes, Verne de la Peña, Christine Muyco, and the college’s several performing groups. Dancers collaborate with composers in UPConemus (Composers for New Music). Young composers who have done music for full ballets are Jesse Lucas for BP’s Darna; Jerrold Tarog for BP’s After Whom; Jed Balsamo for BP’s Crisostomo Ibarra;Teresa Barrozo for the Philippine High School for the Arts’ Sulog sa Kinabuhi (Surge in Life) and the UP Dance Company’s (UPDC) Pavillion 4 and Mata sa Damgo (Eye in Dream);and Toni Muñoz, also for UPDC’s Nasalapu-an (Birthing)and Flight. With very rare chances to repeat a dance, their original music may still live on in concert form or in new choreographed versions.

text:
Dance research and documentation is the process of gathering and recording data on a dance, in the field, dance studio, theater, library, and archives.

Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (later Reyes-Aquino) pioneered dance research in the Philippines. In the 1930s, she combed the countryside for folk dances with fellow scholars photographer Ramon Tolentino and composer Antonino Buenaventura as part of a team created by University of the Philippines (UP) President Jorge Bocobo. The team’s documentation work resulted in the performance of the dances by the UP Folk Song and Dance Club, and the publication of Philippine Folk Dances and Games, 1935, and Philippine National Dances, 1946. Reyes-Aquino’s masterpiece, achieved with the help of the Bureau of Education and provincial researches, was the six-volume Philippine Folk Dances published from 1953 to 1979. Reyes-Aquino set figures, establishing a standard vocabulary for Philippine folk dance and a system of verbal and sign directions that other researchers follow to this day. She also published glossaries and instructional books on folk dance. After Reyes-Aquino, dance research in UP received support in the 1990s, under the Office of Research Coordination and the President’s Committee on Culture and the Arts of the UP.

Other field researchers followed Reyes-Aquino’s example: Libertad V. Fajardo, with her three-volume work Visayan Folk Dances, 1961; Juan C. Miel with Samar Folk Dances, 1973; Jovita Sison Friese, with Philippine Folk Dances from Pangasinan, 1980; Teresita Pascua-Ines with Ilocano Folk Dances, 1973. More recently, Petronila Suarez did studies on Ilonggo folk dances, 2000; Leon Tuy did an analytical study of several Bicol folk dances; and Gloria Cabahug studied the fundamental characteristics of Cebuano folk dances.

Although the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) Filipiniana Folk Music and Dance Committee had started to do research in dance in the 1930s, it was only in the 1950s that the University’s Bayanihan Folk Arts Center, under the leadership of Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, Lucrecia Kasilag, and Isabel Santos, in coordination with PWU provincial branches, organized a comprehensive and systematic field research in folk dance. In 2002, the Bayanihan center and company completed a set of five video films classifying the suites in the company’s repertoire of dances: namely, Cordillera, Maria Clara, Rural, Muslim, and Tribal.

Ramon A. Obusan, former dancer and researcher of the Bayanihan, did extensive documentation of dance on his own after leaving Bayanihan. His invaluable personal video library forms the basis for the staging of folk dances by his dance company, the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group. For Mico Records (n. d.), Obusan published 14 folk dances from various regions in the Philippines. Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, another formidable researcher, studied the dances (including movements, occasions, and costumes) of the Tausug, Sama/Samal, Sama Dilaut (Badjao), and Jama Mapun of the Sulu archipelago and published these in her book Pangalay: Traditional Dances and Related Folk Artistic Expressions, 1983.

Folk dance research can be conducted by observing and joining Folk Arts Theater festivals and workshops, which started in 1978. Dances, such as those performed in the First Philippine Folk Festival in 1981by Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, are introduced mainly to school teachers. The Dance Education Association of the Philippines holds annual folk dance workshops where regional researchers teach their newly discovered dances. The old Kaamulan festivals in Bukidnon and other festivals also allowed researchers to observe and document dances all in one place.

The most prolific association in dance research is the Philippine Folk Dance Society (PFDS). Aside from its yearly workshops held in different parts of the country, PFDS anthologized previously published dances in three volumes of A Classic Collection of Philippine Folk Dances, 2006, 2007, and 2008 . These consolidate choices from the early books of Francisca Reyes-Aquino, Jovita Sison Friese, Juan Miel, Libertad V.Fajardo, Ramon Obusan, and Hadja Badria Jajurie. On the other hand, PFDS’s several volumes of Sayaw (Dance) from 1999 to 2014 anthologize new researches in folk dance from all over the country. These dances are presented and taught at PFDS’s annual workshops. Aside from those taken from Obusan, Sison Friese, and Paz Cielo Belmonte, contributions come from Jose Balcena, Emerita Basilio, Franco Pastor, Petronila Suarez, and new researchers who help disseminate dances from all over the country.

In 1994, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) published Cordillera Ethnic Dances: A Manual for Teachers that documents dances from Abra, Apayao, Benguet, Ifugao, Kalinga, Bontok, and other parts of Mountain Province. Notators of the dances are Salvadora Serrano, Eduardo Laconsay, and Josephine Flores. Whether through the physical education or formalized academic dance and arts program, there are hundreds of theses and dissertations that have enriched the scholarship in Philippine dance. There is a need to make a consolidated listing of these scholarly works found in universities nationwide.

Video film is now an ubiquitous aid in dance research. Movement, color, and sound are recorded all at once, while notation completes the details of the dance. Film, however, is two-dimensional, requiring documentation from various angles, distances, and heights; several cameras or takes may be necessary to accurately portray performances. Despite these limitations in documenting dance in both notation and film (not to mention its cost and the need for periodic verification though time), the use of video has spread, especially with advances in portable digital video cameras. However, access to video documentation, as well as book manuals on dance, is still confined to dance organizations and researchers.

In the 1970s, the Ballet Federation published its own journal of dance. But after a few years, the journal stopped publication and has not been replaced by another regular journal or annual in dance. However, in 2008, a new publication on dance called Runthrough appeared.Edited by Joelle Jacinto, this publication is available online. Under the NCCA, the national dance committee held conferences to upgrade teachers’ academic awareness. The proceedings of the 1998 Philippine international dance conference were published. The NCCA stopped this program for a while, but in the 2000s, it revived workshops and conferences, with its annual international Dance Xchange Festival.

Dance research has been popularized by the Tuklas Sining series of videos and monographs on the Philippine arts of the CCP. To date, the CCP has come out with the Sayaw series: An Essay on Philippine Dance, 1989, by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz and Ramon Obusan; the Philippine Ethnic Dance, 1994, by Villaruz and Obusan; The Spanish Influence on Philippine Dance, 1992, by Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula and Prosperidad M. Arandez; and the The American Colonial and Contemporary Traditions in Philippine Dance, 1994, by Villaruz. Through the CCP, the ASEAN also issued The Traditional Dances: Philippines, 1977, describing and showing three well-known folk dances: itik-itik, habanera botoleña, and kini-kini.

Library or archival research includes the examination of primary materials, including any form of dance notation, choreographic notes and scenarios, correspondence, and related manuscripts. Secondary materials include souvenir programs, posters, flyers, periodical notices, reviews, books, and folios. Libraries now include microfilms of these written or printed materials, and audio and visual recordings. Archives and museums preserve photographs and memorabilia, costumes, musical instruments, designs and librettos, rehearsal and performance schedules, and even account bills. A sizeable amount of dance and music materials is available at the CCP and the Jose Maceda Ethnomusicology Center, UP College of Music.

Three important books that used library and other materials are: Reynaldo Alejandro’s Philippine Dance: Mainstream and Concurrents, 1978, which presents a general survey of the development of ethnic dances, Christian lowland dances, social dances, ballet, and modern dance in the Philippines; Leonor Orosa-Goquingco’s Dances of the Emerald Isles, 1980, which describes the dances of 30 ethnolinguistic groups, among them the Bontok, Ifugao, Kalinga, Aeta, Mangyan, Tagbanwa, Batak, Palawan, Bagobo, Bukidnon, Manobo, Tboli, Tiruray, Tausug, Samal, Maranao, and Maguindanao; and Doreen Fernandez and Rudy Vidad’s In Performance, 1981, which describes in text and pictures the classical modern ballets as well as the original modern dance pieces of Ballet Philippines from 1970 to 1980.

There are a few books which employ sociological, theoretical, and critical viewpoints. Among these are Elena Rivera Mirano’s 100">Subli: One Dance in Four Voices ( Subli: Isang Sayaw sa Apat na Tinig ), 1989, a nuanced reading of the music, literature, movements, and prayer constituting Batangas’s traditional dance form, thesubli; Basilio Esteban Villaruz’s Treading Through 45 Years of Philippine Dance, 2006, an extensive scholarly chronicle of dance history and analysis in the Philippines and the dance world, and Walking Through Philippine Theater, 2012, a three-volume compendium of essays, reviews, dance and theater history, and social biographies of artists written from the 1960s to the 1990s; Rina Angela Corpus’s Defiant Daughters Dancing: Three Independent Women Dance, 2007, a study on the choreographic practices of Myra Beltran, Agnes Locsin, and Kristine Jackson; and Theodore Gonzalves’s The Day the Dancers Stayed, 2010, a critical analysis of the intersections of nation-formation, folk dance, the Philippine Cultural Night in the United States, and Filipinos dancing abroad. First to describe her choreographic process, Agnes Locsin published Philippine Neo-Ethnic Choreography, 2012, which maps the development of the idea of “neo-ethnic” and her process of creating works. A singular book on stage design is Nicanor G. Tiongson’s Salvador T. Bernal: Designing the Stage, 2007, on a prolific and innovative designer for theater and dance. Another welcome addition to dance research in the Philippines is Patrick Alcedo’s Ati-atihan Lives and Panaad: A Promise to the Santo Niño, 2012, both documentary films which record the stories of festival participants and their devotion to the Santo Niño. In featuring the narratives of these participants, these documentaries show multiple layers of a cultural practice which is both spiritual and secular.

Conferences of the World Dance Alliance (WDA) in the Philippines and elsewhere have published proceedings and most contain Filipino contributions. These conferences have been held in Hong Kong, Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan, Japan, China, India, Germany, Canada, Brazil, and USA. WDA’s Asia Pacific Center reviews events through its Asia Pacific Channels,now available online. The International Council of Traditional Music (ICTM) closely links dance and music, thus dance is integral to its studies and conferences, held in Asia and worldwide.

Interviews, which are essential to shed further light on the dances, are available in recorded and transcribed form in libraries and personal collections. Oral histories of a few key dance figures had been done by Reynaldo G. Alejandro for the New York Dance Library’s Dance Collection. The dance degree program at the UP College of Music (UPCMu) also requires dance majors to compile oral histories and write their theses on dance. For a De La Salle University project, Marcelino Foronda Jr recorded Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Tina Santos, and Eddie Elejar.

Any movement notation has its advantages as well as limitations. Experts have continually reexamined Labanotation, the Benesh system, the Eskhol-Wachmann, and other systems (including the newly discovered ancient Chinese system) in light of the old (like those of Fuillet and Arbeau) and new (like those of Nijinsky and Massine) notation systems. The Benesh system is taught in four semesters at the UPCMu; it was offered first by Villaruz and is now taught by Desiree Peralejo Medina. Such meticulous efforts in analyzing systems have made possible the restaging of folk and theatrical dances as close to the original as possible. A few Filipinos such as Lulu Puertollano, Priscilla Minas, and Larry Gabao use Labanotation. Villaruz used the Benesh or choreography system for sections of his ballet, Tropical Tapestry, 1980. Villaruz also did the dance notation for Rivera Mirano’s Subli. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

Another welcome addition to dance research in the Philippines is Patrick Alcedo’s Ati-atihan Lives and Panaad: A Promise to the Santo Niño, 2012, both documentary films which record the stories of festival participants and their devotion to the Santo Niño. In featuring the narratives of these participants, these documentaries show multiple layers of a cultural practice which is both spiritual and secular.

Conferences of the World Dance Alliance (WDA) in the Philippines and elsewhere have published proceedings and most contain Filipino contributions. These conferences have been held in Hong Kong, Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan, Japan, China, India, Germany, Canada, Brazil, and USA. WDA’s Asia Pacific Center reviews events through its Asia Pacific Channels,now available online. The International Council of Traditional Music (ICTM) closely links dance and music, thus dance is integral to its studies and conferences, held in Asia and worldwide.

Interviews, which are essential to shed further light on the dances, are available in recorded and transcribed form in libraries and personal collections. Oral histories of a few key dance figures had been done by Reynaldo G. Alejandro for the New York Dance Library’s Dance Collection. The dance degree program at the UP College of Music (UPCMu) also requires dance majors to compile oral histories and write their theses on dance. For a De La Salle University project, Marcelino Foronda Jr recorded Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, Tina Santos, and Eddie Elejar.

Any movement notation has its advantages as well as limitations. Experts have continually reexamined Labanotation, the Benesh system, the Eskhol-Wachmann, and other systems (including the newly discovered ancient Chinese system) in light of the old (like those of Fuillet and Arbeau) and new (like those of Nijinsky and Massine) notation systems. The Benesh system is taught in four semesters at the UPCMu; it was offered first by Villaruz and is now taught by Desiree Peralejo Medina. Such meticulous efforts in analyzing systems have made possible the restaging of folk and theatrical dances as close to the original as possible. A few Filipinos such as Lulu Puertollano, Priscilla Minas, and Larry Gabao use Labanotation. Villaruz used the Benesh or choreography system for sections of his ballet, Tropical Tapestry, 1980. Villaruz also did the dance notation for Rivera Mirano’s Subli. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz
